messages.content: What is the minimum number of workers required for an establishment to be exempt from the provisions of this Act?

Less than five workers XLII OF 2006] [11 October, 2006] An Act to amend and consolidate the laws relating to employment of workers, relations between workers and employers, determination of minimum rates of wages, payment of wages, compensation for injuries to workers during working hours, formation of trade unions, raising and settlement of industrial disputes, health, safety, welfare and working conditions and environment of workers and apprenticeship and matters ancillary thereto WHEREAS it is expedient and necessary to amend and consolidate the laws relating to employment of workers, relations between workers and employers, determination of minimum rates of wages, payment of wages, compensation for injuries to workers during working hours, formation of trade unions, raising and settlement of industrial disputes, health, safety, welfare and working conditions and environment of workers and apprenticeship and matters ancillary thereto; It is hereby enacted as follows:- CHAPTER I PRELIMINARY 1
What exactly are the provisions of this Act that establishments with less than five workers are exempt from?

The provisions of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 relate to minimum wages, working hours, overtime work, leave and public holidays, and other worker protections. Establishments with less than five workers are exempt from these provisions.
Do establishments with less than five workers still need to comply with other labour laws or regulations in Bangladesh?

Yes, even though they may be exempt from the provisions of the Labour Act, establishments with less than five workers must still comply with other relevant labour laws and regulations, such as tax laws and occupational health and safety guidelines.
A small retail store with only one worker is hiring additional staff. Is the employer required to register their business and obtain a permit under the Bangladesh Labour Act?
Yes, as per Section 3 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, all establishments employing any person are required to be registered and obtain a permit.
A garment factory with five workers is being closed down due to economic downturn. Is the employer entitled to lay off all employees without following the proper termination procedures?

No, as per Section 25 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, an employer can only terminate employment by giving one month's written notice or by paying severance compensation equivalent to one month's wages for each completed year of service. The employer must also follow the required procedures for closure and payment of benefits.
Which establishments and workers are NOT subject to the provisions of Chapter XII, XIII, or XIV of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?

A small manufacturing company in Dhaka with a workforce of 10 employees has hired two casual workers for a short-term project. Is the application of Chapter XII (Wages) to these casual workers?

Yes, wages are payable to all workmen regardless of their employment type or duration. A shipping company based in Chittagong has hired a foreign seaman for a six-month contract. Does this seaman fall under the provisions of Chapter XII (Wages) and other chapters as per the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
No, seamen employed on board merchant ships are exempt from the provisions of Chapters XII, XIII, and XIV in cases other than application of these chapters.
What is the effect of sub-section (3) of Section 1 on the applicability of this Act?

This Act shall not apply to establishments or workers specified in clause (a), (b), (c), (d), security printing press, ordnance factory, institutions run for treatment, care, or service of sick, disabled, aged, destitute, handicapped, orphan, abandoned woman or child or widow, but not run for profit or gain

Establishments or workers specified in clause (a), (b), (c), (d), security printing press, ordnance factory, institutions run for treatment, care, or service of sick, disabled, aged, destitute, handicapped, orphan, abandoned woman or child or widow, but not run for profit or gain

Establishments or workers specified in clause (a), (b), (c), (d), security printing press, ordnance factory, institutions run for treatment, care, or service of sick, disabled, aged, destitute, handicapped, orphan, abandoned woman or child or widow, but not run for profit or gain

This Act shall not apply to establishments or workers specified in clause (a), (b), (c), (d), security printing press, ordnance factory, institutions run for treatment, care, or service of sick, disabled, aged, destitute, handicapped, orphan, abandoned woman or child or widow, but not run for profit or gain
What is the meaning of 'security printing press' in the context of Bangladesh Labour Law?
A security printing press refers to a facility engaged in the production of documents such as passports, identity cards, and other sensitive materials for national security purposes.
Can establishments running for treatment, care, or service of vulnerable groups be exempted from certain provisions of the Act if they are run for non-profit objectives?

Yes, institutions that are established to provide treatment, care, or service to vulnerable groups such as sick, disabled, aged, destitute, handicapped, orphan, abandoned woman or child or widow, but not for profit or gain, may be exempted from certain provisions of the Act.

A company with 100 employees, engaged in manufacturing leather goods, has just hired 20 new workers. The workers are primarily female and have been working for more than 6 months. However, the employer has not provided them with a written contract or any record of their employment. How would you advise this HR manager to handle this situation?

The employer should immediately issue a written employment contract to the new workers, as it is mandatory under Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018). The contract should specify the terms and conditions of employment, including wages, working hours, breaks, and any other benefits. Failure to do so may result in non-compliance with labour laws, which could lead to penalties and reputational damage.

A small textile workshop in Dhaka city has only 5 employees, all of whom are migrant workers from India. The employer pays them a daily wage of BDT 800 each. However, the workers have been complaining about the poor working conditions, including lack of natural light and inadequate ventilation. What would be the appropriate course of action to address this situation?

The HR manager should conduct an immediate inspection of the workshop to identify the specific hazards affecting the employees' health and safety. If any hazards are found, the employer must take corrective measures within a specified timeframe (usually 3 days) 2006. Additionally, the employer should also consider providing benefits such as social security contributions, housing allowance, or training opportunities to improve working conditions and overall well-being of the migrant workers.
According to Section 1(4), what is the exception in terms of application of this Act to Government servants?

[In the case of application of Chapter II] any shop or industrial or commercial establishment owned and directly operated by the Government where the workers are governed by the conduct rules applicable to the Government servants
What is the exception regarding the application of Bangladesh Labour Act to Government servants, as per Section 1(4)?
any shop or industrial or commercial establishment owned and directly operated by the Government where the workers are governed by the conduct rules applicable to the Government servants
Under what circumstances is the Bangladesh Labour Act not applicable to Government servants, according to Section 1(4)?
any shop or industrial or commercial establishment owned and directly operated by the Government where the workers are governed by the conduct rules applicable to the Government servants
To what extent does the Bangladesh Labour Act apply to Government-owned establishments, as specified in Section 1(4)?
any shop or industrial or commercial establishment owned and directly operated by the Government where the workers are governed by the conduct rules applicable to the Government servants
What is the treatment of government servants who work in establishments owned and directly operated by the Government, but are not governed by conduct rules applicable to government servants?
These workers are entitled to the benefits under Chapter II, but only if they are employed on a regular/ permanent basis, and not as casual or daily wage labourers.

Can you provide an example of an establishment owned and directly operated by the Government where government servants would be governed by conduct rules applicable to the Government servants, rather than being subject to Chapter II of the Bangladesh Labour Act?

Yes, a hospital managed by the Ministry of Health or a school run by the Education Ministry could be an example. In these cases, government servants working in these establishments would be bound by their respective department's conduct rules.

A small-scale garment factory with 200 employees is facing a dispute between the employer and some employees who are claiming overtime pay for working on weekends. The Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 requires employers to pay overtime wages. However, the company claims that it did not receive any notice from the Ministry of Labor regarding such notification. According to the law, what should be done by the employer?

The employer must provide information about receipt of notice from the Ministry of Labor and prove that they have complied with all provisions of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 regarding overtime pay. If there is no proof, the employees may file a complaint with the Department of Labor and the case will be investigated.

A private company in Dhaka employs 500 workers in its IT sector. The workers are not provided with any medical facilities or insurance benefits as per the Bangladesh Labour Act 2018. However, the company claims that it is following a government-approved health and safety policy for IT sector employees. According to the law, what should be done by the company?

The company must provide its employees with basic medical facilities and insurance benefits as per the Bangladesh Labour Act 2018. Even if the company is following a government-approved policy, it still needs to comply with specific provisions of the Act regarding health and safety in the workplace. The company may need to reevaluate its policy or make necessary amendments to meet the requirements of the law.
What is the definition of 'retirement' in Section 2(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
The act of leaving employment voluntarily or through any other means, resulting in the cessation of an employee's service
What is the standard definition of 'retirement' under the Bangladesh Labour Act?
The act of leaving employment voluntarily or through any other means, resulting in the cessation of an employee's service
How is retirement defined under Section 2(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act?
The act of leaving employment voluntarily or through any other means, resulting in the cessation of an employee's service
What constitutes 'retirement' as per the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The act of leaving employment voluntarily or through any other means, resulting in the cessation of an employee's service

A manufacturing company with 50 employees in the textile industry has an employee, Mr. X, who has worked for the company for over 10 years. Due to health reasons, Mr. X is unable to perform his duties. The company offers him voluntary retirement with a 2-year salary guarantee and other benefits. Is this a valid reason for Mr. X's retirement under Section 2(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Yes, this can be considered a valid reason for Mr. X's retirement as he is leaving employment voluntarily due to health reasons, resulting in the cessation of his service.

A small retail shop with 20 employees in Dhaka has an employee, Ms. Y, who has been working there for 5 years. After a performance review, the company decides to terminate her contract due to 'company restructuring' without offering any severance package or retirement benefits. Is this a compliant decision under Section 2(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?

No, this is not a compliant decision as it does not fall under the definition of 'retirement' in Section 2(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006. The company should have offered severance package or retirement benefits to Ms. Y instead of simply terminating her contract without any notice.
What is the definition of 'partial disablement' under Section 1A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

Partial disablement means a temporary or permanent nature of disability that reduces the earning capacity of a worker in any employment where he was engaged at the time of the accident resulting in the disablement.
What is the concept of partial disablement under Section 1A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, specifically in relation to its impact on a worker's earning capacity?

Partial disablement means a temporary or permanent nature of disability that reduces the earning capacity of a worker in any employment where he was engaged at the time of the accident resulting in the disablement.
How is partial disablement under Section 1A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 defined in terms of its effect on a worker's ability to earn an income?

Partial disablement means a temporary or permanent nature of disability that reduces the earning capacity of a worker in any employment where he was engaged at the time of the accident resulting in the disablement.

What is the extent of partial disablement under Section 1A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, specifically in relation to its impact on a worker's ability to continue working in their current employment?

Partial disablement means a temporary or permanent nature of disability that reduces the earning capacity of a worker in any employment where he was engaged at the time of the accident resulting in the disablement.
What is the procedure for claiming partial disablement benefits under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The claimant must submit an application to the concerned Insurance Company or the State Insurance Corporation within one year from the date of occurrence of the accident.
How does the employer's liability for partial disablement differ from other types of disability benefits under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The employer is required to pay compensation and provide medical treatment to the claimant, in addition to providing temporary or permanent substitution for the disabled worker.

Rahim, a 35-year-old software engineer at a mid-sized IT company (50 employees) in Dhaka, is involved in an accident during his daily commute. He suffers from a temporary injury that affects one of his hands, leaving him with limited dexterity for about six months. The company's medical policy requires employees to undergo a rehabilitation program and return to work as soon as possible. However, Rahim's doctor advises him to take another 2-3 months off due to the severity of the injury. Will Rahim be considered partially disabled under Section 1A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

Yes, Rahim will be considered partially disabled A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 because his temporary injury has reduced his earning capacity in his current employment at the IT company for a period of time.

Fatema, a 28-year-old factory worker at a small garment manufacturing unit (20 employees) in Chittagong, suffers from a permanent disability after being injured during an accident on the job. The medical board's report indicates that Fatema will need to undergo regular medical treatment and rehabilitation for the rest of her life due to a severe injury to her leg. According to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, what are the entitlements and benefits available to Fatema?

A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, as Fatema has suffered from a permanent disability, she is entitled to various benefits including medical treatment, rehabilitation, pension, and compensation. However, the company may be required to provide her with a suitable job or re-employment opportunities, taking into account her reduced earning capacity due to her disability.
What is considered as a 'festival allowance' under Section 2A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Festival allowance means festival allowance of the workers of factories and establishments which is paid on the occasion of respective religious festivals as determined by the Rules.
What constitutes a 'festival allowance' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
A festival allowance is paid on the occasion of respective religious festivals as determined by the Rules.
In what circumstances does an employer provide a 'festival allowance' to their workers in accordance with Section 2A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
An employer provides a festival allowance on the occasion of respective religious festivals as determined by the Rules.
What type of allowance is specifically referred to as 'festival allowance' under the provisions of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
A festival allowance is a payment made by an employer for the workers of factories and establishments on specific religious festivals, as specified in the Rules.
What are the conditions for a factory or establishment to pay festival allowance to its workers?
According to Section 2A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, a factory or establishment is required to pay festival allowance to its workers if they observe any religious festival during the year.
Can an employer reduce the amount of festival allowance paid to their workers, and if so, under what circumstances?

According to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, an employer can adjust the rate of festival allowance based on the cost of living index. However, any reduction should be done in consultation with the workers' union and with a minimum reduction of not less than 10%.

A medium-sized manufacturing company (100-500 employees) in the garment industry wants to pay its workers a festival allowance of BDT 500 each during Eid-al-Fitr. However, one worker informs the HR department that she is not Muslim and would like to be exempt from receiving the festival allowance. What are the implications under Section 2A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

Under Section 2A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, a festival allowance must be paid to workers who observe the respective religious festivals as determined by the Rules. Since the worker is not Muslim, she should not receive the festival allowance. The company should either exempt her from receiving the allowance or provide alternative compensation as per the law. Failure to comply may result in legal consequences.

A small-scale construction company (less than 50 employees) in Dhaka has been operating for over 10 years and has a total of 25 migrant workers from Nepal who are on temporary work visas. The company wants to pay its workers a festival allowance of BDT 1000 each during Eid-al-Adha. However, the migrant workers are not eligible to receive the festival allowance under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 because they do not hold any employment contract with the company. What is the correct course of action?

The company should provide alternative compensation or a one-time payment to the migrant workers as per the law, considering their temporary work arrangement. Paying them the festival allowance would be in violation of Section 2A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, which requires that only employees who hold an employment contract with the establishment receive the allowance.
Who is considered an 'officer' in the case of a trade union under Section 7 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
An officer, in the case of a trade union, means any member of the executive committee thereof, but does not include an auditor or legal adviser.
Who is considered an 'officer' of a trade union according to Section 7 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

Under what circumstances is an individual considered an officer of a trade union for the purposes of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018)?
Any member of the executive committee thereof, but does not include an auditor or legal adviser
What happens if an executive committee member is also the auditor or legal adviser of the trade union?
In such a case, the officer designation would not apply to that specific individual, as it excludes auditors and legal advisers.
Are there any specific roles or positions within a trade union that are automatically considered officers under Section 7 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
the following individuals are automatically considered officers: president, vice-president(s), general secretary, treasurer, and other executive committee members.

A factory with 500 employees, operating in the textile industry, has a trade union representing its workers. One of the executive committee members is caught shoplifting during working hours. The employee has been a part of the union for three years and serves as an officer. What are the implications of this incident on the employee's role as an officer under Section 7 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The employee's actions may lead to disciplinary action, but their role as an officer is not automatically terminated. However, if the court finds that the employee's actions compromised the integrity and credibility of the trade union, it could result in removal from office. The employee should be given a fair opportunity to explain themselves and face consequences within the framework set by the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006.

A small IT firm with 20 employees hires a freelance auditor who occasionally reviews its financial records. The auditor has been advised by the company's legal team on labor matters, including trade union formation and recognition under Section 7 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. Can this freelancer be considered an officer in the eyes of the law?

No, according to 2006, an auditor is specifically excluded from being considered an 'officer' of a trade union. Although the freelancer has been advised on labor matters by the company's legal team, their freelance nature and lack of formal affiliation with the trade union preclude them from meeting the definition of an officer.
What is the definition of 'working hour' under Section 8 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Working hour means the time during which the workers employed are at the disposal of the employer, excluding any interval allowed for rest and meals.
What constitutes a 'working hour' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The time during which workers are at the disposal of the employer, excluding intervals allowed for rest and meals.
How is a worker's availability calculated to determine their working hours under the Labour Act?
The time during which workers are at the disposal of the employer, excluding intervals allowed for rest and meals.
What does the term 'working hour' encompass in terms of employee worktime under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The time during which workers are at the disposal of the employer, excluding intervals allowed for rest and meals.
How does the 'time during which the workers employed are at the disposal of the employer' definition encompass breaks and intervals allowed for rest and meals?

The working hours do not include time allocated specifically for rest periods, meal breaks, or other activities that allow employees to rest and recharge. However, it's essential to ensure that these breaks are not so long that they significantly impact the employee's overall workday.
Does the 'time during which the workers employed are at the disposal of the employer' definition apply to overtime hours, or is there a separate provision for that?

While the working hour definition primarily focuses on regular working hours, overtime hours are covered under 2006. Overtime hours are calculated separately and must be approved in writing by the employee.

A manufacturing company with 50 employees operates 8 hours a day, 6 days a week. However, the employees are given an extra hour of break time every day. Is this in compliance with Section 8 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

No, this is not in compliance with 2006. The working hours for the company should be calculated by considering only the actual working time (8 hours) plus any intervals allowed for rest and meals. In this case, an extra hour of break time needs to be excluded from the total working hours.

An employee in a private school with 100 students is required to work 12 hours on Saturdays during the academic year. However, the employee is promised a salary increase after completing the academic year. Is this compliance with Section 8 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

No, this is not in compliance with 2006. The working hours for an employee should be limited to 9 hours per day and 48 hours per week. Requiring an employee to work 12 hours on a Saturday exceeds the permissible limit and needs to be revised accordingly.

A factory has a total of 10 workers employed on any day. If one worker is injured in an accident resulting in partial disablement, what percentage of the working hour should be provided as leave to the injured worker?
Refer to 2006, which states that the employer shall provide a leave of not less than 25 days per year for the injured worker due to partial disablement.
What is the minimum leave entitlement for an injured worker with partial disablement in a Bangladesh factory, as specified by law?

How many working hours should be compensated to an employee who suffers partial disablement due to an accident at work in Bangladesh?
Refer to 2006, which states that the employer shall provide a leave of not less than 25 days per year for the injured worker
What percentage of their expected working hours should be granted as paid leave to an employee with partial disablement due to a work-related accident in Bangladesh?
Refer to 2006, which states that the employer shall provide a leave of not less than 25 days per year for the injured worker
How does the employer determine the leave period for the injured worker, considering that a partial disablement may affect their ability to work for only a fraction of the total hours?

The employer shall determine the leave period based on the severity and duration of the injury. The injured worker's average daily working hours should be taken into consideration to calculate the applicable leave period.
Does the provision of 25 days' leave per year for partial disablement include additional benefits such as medical treatment, compensation, or other forms of support?

No, the 25 days' leave provision specifically covers the time required for the injured worker to recover from their injury. However, the employer is required to provide necessary medical treatment and compensation as per the provisions of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006.

A medium-sized clothing factory ( employs 100 workers) has a total of 30 days paid annual leave for all employees. One employee, who is also the union representative, will be on maternity leave for the next three months. How much of the paid annual leave will be reserved for this employee?
The factory should reserve at least 75% (225 out of 300 days) of the paid annual leave for the employee on maternity leave.

A small-scale IT company in Bangladesh has a total of 20 employees. The company has a policy to provide an additional day of casual leave per year for each employee. Due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, one employee is required to work from home and will not be able to take their allocated casual leave for a period of six months. How should the company handle this situation?
The company should consider providing an alternative day off or a paid leave for the employee when they are allowed to return to the office, 2006.
What does the term 'subsistence allowance' mean under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
It means half of the basic wages, dearness allowance, and adhoc or interim wages.
What is the proportion of basic wages, dearness allowance, and adhoc or interim wages that constitutes a subsistence allowance under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The minimum percentage is not specified, it may be decided by the employers. Can the subsistence allowance be deducted from an employee's salary if their wages are paid late or there is a delay in payment?
Yes, the employer can deduct the subsistence allowance for a maximum of three months if there is a delay in payment of wages exceeding two weeks.

To calculate the subsistence allowance, first find the basic wages including dearness allowance: 15000 x (1 + 0.3) = 19500. Then, divide it by two to get the subsistence allowance: 19500 / 2 = 9750

What is the total amount of gratuity an employee can receive if they have completed 15 years of service?
45 days (for each year) * 15 = 675 days, converted to monetary value based on the prevailing wage rate and number of working days
Can gratuity be paid in advance or is it only payable upon termination of service?

Gratuity is generally payable upon termination of service. However, some cases may allow for advance payment with permission from relevant authorities, but this must be in accordance with the Labour Act and specific company policies

A mid-sized IT company with 100 employees in Dhaka has an employee, Mr. X, who has completed 5 years of service. The employee is leaving the company to join another firm. What amount of gratuity should be paid to Mr. X upon termination of his service?

As per Bangladesh Labour Law, an employee entitled to receive gratuity upon termination of service gets 30 days of gratuity for every completed year of service. Since Mr. X has completed 5 years of service, he is entitled to 2 months (30 days) of gratuity.
What is the definition of 'retrenchment' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The termination of services of workers by the employer on grounds of redundancy.
What constitutes 'redundancy' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

According to the Act, redundancy occurs when the work or services of a worker are reduced due to the permanent closure of a factory, the permanent reduction in the volume of the output of a factory, or any other permanent change in the nature of the work or services of a worker.
How does the employer determine the 'redundant' employees under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The employer must give an advance notice of at least three months to the affected workers and provide them with a fair opportunity to seek employment elsewhere. The employer can also consider factors like seniority, length of service, and skills when determining which employees will be retrenched.

A leading garment manufacturer with 500 employees in Dhaka is facing financial difficulties. The company has decided to retrench 100 workers, citing redundancy due to the global decline in the garment industry. However, only a few dozen workers have been notified of their retrenchment, and many are unaware of the reason for termination. Is this procedure compliant with the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

No, this procedure is not compliant with the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. Section 30 of the act requires that at least 3 months' notice be given to affected employees before retrenchment takes place, and that a written notification be provided to each employee. Furthermore, the employer must demonstrate that retrenchment is due to redundancy and provide evidence to support this claim.

A small bakery in Chittagong has been operating for 10 years with a workforce of 50 employees. Due to reduced demand during Ramadan, the owner decides to temporarily reduce staff by 20% (10 workers) without following any formal notice period or severance package. Is this action allowed under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

No, this action is not allowed under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. Although the act allows for temporary retrenchment during exceptional circumstances, such as a natural disaster or government directive, no such circumstance has been specified here. Moreover, the bakery must have followed the necessary procedures, including providing written notice to affected employees and offering severance pay equivalent to one month's wages per year of service.

The management should inform the Labour Department immediately and try to resolve the issue through negotiations with the union representatives or individual workers if possible. They should also document the incident, including the reason for the slowdown and any attempts made to resolve it.

A small-scale shop owner in Dhaka has three employees who have not received their monthly salaries on time due to a dispute over the payment of overtime wages. The employees are considering a 'go-slow' action to pressure the employer into resolving the issue. What should the HR/Management team do?

What are the qualifications for an individual to be a trade unionist under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
An individual must not have been dismissed or required to leave their employment solely because of their membership in a trade union federation.
How do trade union federations exercise their right to negotiate with the government and the private sector employers in Bangladesh as per the Labour Act 2006?

Trade union federations can submit a written request to the government, stating their demands, which will be considered by the government. However, the government is not obligated to accept these demands.

A manufacturing company in Dhaka with 500 employees is considering dismissing two union leaders of the employees' association. What are the HR's responsibilities under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 if the employees resist the dismissal?

The HR must consult the union leaders as per Section 25(2) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, and notify the Department of Labour Affairs within 15 days. If the employees continue to resist, the HR may need to take disciplinary action against them for violating the act.

What is the composition of an executive committee?
An executive committee consists of persons entrusted with the management of a trade union's affairs, as mentioned in its constitution.
Can an executive committee be formed without a trade union constitution?
No, an executive committee cannot be formed without a trade union constitution. The constitution must specifically entrust its management to this body.

The executive committee, as per Section 24 of the Act, should consist of at least one-third of the members elected by the trade union. Assuming there are 100 unionized workers, the minimum number of members for the executive committee would be 33 (1/3 of 100). Therefore, management representatives and employee representatives from different departments or unions can also join this committee to ensure representation from all sections.

A large IT company in Bangladesh with over 2,000 employees has a union that represents the interests of 20% of its workforce (400 employees). The company has been accused of not following the procedures for conducting elections and nominations as per the Act. What should be the first step taken by the HR department to address this issue?

The first step should be to conduct fair and transparent elections in accordance with Section 15 of the Act, which outlines the procedures for trade union elections. The company should also ensure that all eligible employees are given an equal opportunity to participate in the elections. If necessary, the HR department may need to consult the trade union representatives or seek guidance from a labor expert to ensure compliance with the Act.
What is considered 'maternity benefit' under the Act?
'Maternity benefit' means the sum of money payable under the provisions of Chapter IV to a woman worker with leave other benefits on the ground of her being a mother (Section 34)

Maternity benefit means the sum of money payable under the provisions of Chapter IV to a woman worker with leave other benefits on the ground of her being a mother (Section 34)

The maternity benefit includes the sum of money payable under the provisions of Chapter IV to a woman worker, along with leave other benefits on the ground of her being a mother

A worker dies due to an accident at work. What type of dependant is entitled to receive compensation?
The widow, minor child, unmarried daughter or a widowed mother of the deceased worker are considered dependants entitled to receive compensation (Section 30(a) and (b))

The widow, minor child, unmarried daughter or a widowed mother of the deceased worker are considered dependants

The amount of compensation payable to dependants in case of accidental death varies based on the number and relationship of the dependant(s), as specified (a) and (b) of the Bangladesh Labour Act.
Can a worker's dependent receive compensation if they are not married at the time of their death, but were married before their death?
Yes, in such cases, an unmarried daughter or a widowed mother of the deceased worker would be entitled to receive compensation.

Despite the lack of safety training and equipment maintenance records, Mr. Iqbal Ali's widow, minor child, unmarried daughter, or a widowed mother would be considered dependants entitled to receive compensation (a) and (b) of the Bangladesh Labour Act.

A construction company with 50 employees, employing migrant workers from India, has an in-house medical facility. One of the migrant workers, Mr. Rohan, is injured on the job site and suffers a serious head injury that requires hospitalization for several days. As Mr. Rohan is an injured employee who has suffered a serious head injury requiring hospitalization, he would be entitled to receive medical compensation under the Bangladesh Labour Act, as well as other benefits such as wage protection and pension contribution while he is unable to work.

An IT company in Dhaka with over 100 employees has a new policy requiring all employees to work overtime for at least 4 days a week. An employee, who is also the union representative, objects to the policy, citing Section 26 of the Bangladesh Labour Act. Additionally, the dismissed employee may file a complaint with the Labour Department or a court, seeking reinstatement and damages. The employer should have consulted with the union representative before implementing the new policy, and obtained an order from the Director General or a Labour Inspector for the dismissal.

Yes, this action could be considered a lock-out as it was declared in contravention of the provisions of Chapter XIV of the Act. Can an employer unilaterally deduct money from an employee's wages for any reason, including house accommodation, light, water, medical facilities, or other amenities?
No. Such deductions are excluded by general or special order by the Government.

A competent officer is responsible for ensuring compliance with the Bangladesh Labour Act and its regulations, conducting inspections, investigating complaints, and enforcing labour laws and regulations within their respective establishments.

Additionally, workers who are hired to perform specific tasks unrelated to the machinery, such as cleaning or administrative work, may also be classified as employees.

A factory employing 50 workers in a textile mill, with an annual turnover of Tk. 500 million, installs a new prime mover to increase efficiency. Is the installation of this machinery covered under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

Yes, as the new prime mover is considered 'machinery' and its installation would be subject to the provisions of the act, including any necessary safety measures, employee training, and compliance with labor regulations.

A small startup in Dhaka with 10 employees, offers a benefit-in-kind (BIK) scheme to its employees by providing them with company-owned bicycles. Is this BIK scheme considered 'machinery' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

Yes, under Section 25B of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018), a laid-off worker is entitled to receive full wages and benefits for the remaining period of employment, as well as an amount equivalent to one month's salary in lieu of notice.

What happens if the employee is still unable to perform their job duties after an additional three-month extension of the probationary period?
The employer and employee must enter into a new employment agreement, which can be for a fixed term or at-will, as per section (8) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006.

Rahul, a skilled electrician, is hired by a construction company in Dhaka with 50 employees. He has been working for the company for three months and his work quality is still not satisfactory. A manufacturing company with 50 employees in the textile industry has been on a strike for two days. The management has directed an employee to stay at their place of work following the stoppage, but the employee is not allowed to leave without permission from the management. After 6 hours, the employee requests to take leave. Is the employer required to pay the employee's wages?

Yes, as per the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018), if an employee is directed to stay at their place of work following a stoppage for more than 1 hour, they are entitled to wages. In this case, since the employee has been instructed to stay for 6 hours without being allowed to leave, the employer must pay the employee's wages.

A small retail shop with 10 employees in Dhaka city has a policy of making an employee work overtime (beyond their regular working hours) every evening. On a particular day, one employee is instructed to stay late for 2 hours after closing time without permission from the management or the employee's consent. Does this contravene any provision of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018)?

Yes, making an employee work overtime without their consent and without permission from the management or the employee's union representative (if applicable) is a violation of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. As per Section 61(1)(b), employers are not allowed to make any employee work more than 9 hours in a single day, and exceeding this limit without consent is a serious breach of labour laws. The employer must take corrective action and compensate the employee for the extra hours worked.

Since there was no prior notice given, the employer's obligation to pay severance wages may be disputed. However, the employer must provide a reasonable amount of notice in accordance with the Labour Act. If the government ban occurs suddenly and beyond the employer's control, the employer might be exempt from paying full severance wages. But they should still provide minimum wages for the maximum period the employee was employed. The exact provisions will depend on specific circumstances.

A factory employing 200 workers in the construction sector fails to pay its employees their monthly wages on time, resulting in a 2-day delay. What are the potential consequences of this action under Bangladesh Labour Law?

Does the employer have to pay severance package or any compensation to the retrenched worker, in addition to the one months notice?

Yes, as per Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, the employer is required to pay severance package (which includes a certain percentage of last drawn salary for each year of continuous service) and other benefits to the retrenched worker
Is there any provision for re-engagement of retrenched workers after serving notice period?

Yes, if the employer desires to re-engage the retrenched worker within two months from the date of giving notice, he shall be entitled to re-engagement on the same or a higher post with the same remuneration and other terms and conditions of service as they were enjoying prior to his retrenchment

A manufacturing company with 50 employees in the textile industry has two workers, Rohan and Rifat, who have been serving for over a year. The company decides to retrench both of them due to economic downturn. How should the employer handle this situation in accordance with Bangladesh Labour Law?

The employer must give 1 month's notice in writing mentioning the reasons for their retrenchment as per Section 25 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018). The employer should also consider providing severance pay as per the law, which is 60 days' wages for every completed year of service. In this case, since both Rohan and Rifat have been serving for over a year, they are entitled to 120 days' worth of severance pay each.

A small retail shop with 10 employees in Dhaka decides to retrench one employee, Afiq, due to slow sales. However, Afiq has been serving the company for over three years and is the only permanent staff member. The employer wants to avoid paying severance pay. How can they justify their decision?

The employer cannot justify not paying severance pay to Afiq simply because of slow sales or the desire to avoid paying. According to Section 25B of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018), an employee who has been serving for over three years is entitled to 3 months' wages as severance pay, regardless of the reason for retrenchment. The employer must provide Afiq with 3 months' notice in writing and pay him the required severance amount.
What is the procedure for retrenchment of workers, including notice to be given to the last known address of the retrenched worker?

The employer shall send a notice to the last known address of the retrenched worker asking him to apply for employment, and any worker who applies for re-employment in response to such request shall be given preference. (Section 21)
What if the retrenched worker does not have a last known address?
In such cases, the employer may send notice to the workplace or any other address where the worker is likely to be found.
Is there any time limit for the employer to notify the retrenched worker and allow them to re-apply for employment?
No specific time limit is mentioned in the Labour Act, but it is generally recommended that notice should be given as soon as possible after the decision to retrench has been made.

A mid-sized clothing factory (with 200 employees) in Dhaka wants to retrench 20 workers due to decreased demand. The Bangladesh Labour Act requires that the employer gives notice to the last known address of the retrenched worker, but one of the retrenched workers is a migrant worker who has lost contact with his family and doesn't have any fixed address in Dhaka. What should the HR manager do?

The HR manager should try to locate the migrant worker's last known address through various means such as his employer or family members, if available. If not possible, the HR manager can provide written notice at the workplace address, mentioning that the worker will be given preference for re-employment once he responds to the notice. Additionally, the HR manager should document all efforts made to contact the migrant worker and update him on any progress.

A small pharmaceutical factory (with 50 employees) in Chittagong is facing financial difficulties and needs to retrench 10 workers due to production cuts. The Bangladesh Labour Act states that the employer must give a minimum of one month's notice to each worker before retrenchment. However, some of the retrenched workers have family obligations and need to continue working for another company to meet their ends. What should the HR manager do?

The HR manager should provide a minimum of one month's notice as per the Bangladesh Labour Act, but also offer support to the retrenched workers in finding alternative employment. The HR manager can facilitate meetings with the retrenched workers and other employers to help them find new job opportunities. Additionally, the HR manager can provide outplacement assistance, such as resume writing and interview preparation, to increase their chances of getting hired by another company.
Under what conditions can a worker be dismissed without a notice or wages in lieu of a notice?
A worker may be dismissed without a notice or without wages in lieu of a notice if he is convicted of any criminal offence; or found guilty of misconduct under section 24. (Section 23(1)(a) and (b))
Under what circumstances can an employer terminate a worker's employment without providing prior notice or payment in lieu of notice?
A worker may be dismissed without a notice or without wages in lieu of a notice if he is convicted of any criminal offence; or found guilty of misconduct under section 24.
What exceptions allow an employer to dismiss an employee immediately, without providing notice or compensation for the lost time?
A worker may be dismissed without a notice or without wages in lieu of a notice if he is convicted of any criminal offence; or found guilty of misconduct under section 24.
Are there specific situations where an employer can terminate a worker's employment immediately, without observing the required notice period or providing payment in lieu of that notice?
A worker may be dismissed without a notice or without wages in lieu of a notice if he is convicted of any criminal offence; or found guilty of misconduct under section 24.
Can a worker be dismissed without notice or wages in lieu if the misconduct is related to workplace safety and health?
No, a worker cannot be dismissed without notice or wages in lieu solely on the basis of a workplace safety and health infraction, unless it is considered serious misconduct.
Can an employer deduct wages in lieu of notice if the worker has already received their full monthly wages?
Yes, an employer can deduct wages in lieu of notice, but only to the extent of the amount that would have been due to the worker had they not received their full monthly wages previously.

A small textile manufacturing company with 50 employees in Dhaka has an employee, Mr. X, who is found guilty of theft under section 24 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. The company wants to dismiss Mr. X without providing a notice period or his wages in lieu of notice. Is this permissible?

Yes, it is permissible. As per section 23(1)(a) and (b) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, an employee can be dismissed without a notice period or his wages in lieu of notice if he is convicted of any criminal offence or found guilty of misconduct under section 24.

A large IT company with over 500 employees in Chittagong has two employees, Mr. A and Mr. B, who are involved in a dispute between them. The HR department decides to dismiss both Mr. A and Mr. B without providing notice periods or their wages in lieu of notice. Is this permissible under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

No, it is not permissible. Section 23(1)(a) and (b) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 requires that an employee can only be dismissed without a notice period or his wages in lieu of notice if he is convicted of any criminal offence or found guilty of misconduct under section 24. Dismissal without notice for internal disputes between employees would not be considered valid grounds.
What is the compensation payable to a discharged worker who completes not less than one year of continuous service?
The employer shall pay the discharged worker, as compensation, 30 (thirty) days' wages for every completed year of his service. (Section 22(2))
What happens if the discharged worker completes less than one year of continuous service?
The employer shall pay a fraction of the wages corresponding to the proportion of completed years of service.
Is there any cap on the total compensation payable to the discharged worker under Section 22(2)?
No, there is no specific cap mentioned in Section 22(2) for the total compensation payable to a discharged worker who completes not less than one year of continuous service.

A 25-year-old female employee, working as a sewing machine operator in a garment factory with 5 employees and 3 management staff, completes 12 months of continuous service. She is discharged due to 'restructuring'. According to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, what compensation should she receive?

The employer shall pay the discharged worker, as compensation, 30 (thirty) days' wages for every completed year of her service. Since she has completed 12 months of continuous service, she is entitled to 12 * 30 = 360 (three hundred sixty) days' wages.
What acts are treated as misconduct under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
[List of misconduct acts mentioned in Section 24(4), including willful disobedience, theft, habitual absence without leave, disorderliness, and habitual breach of any law or rule or regulation]
What are the specific actions considered as misconduct under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Willful disobedience, theft, habitual absence without leave, disorderliness, and habitual breach of any law or rule or regulation
List the types of behaviour that can lead to disciplinary action under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006.
Willful disobedience, theft, habitual absence without leave, disorderliness, and habitual breach of any law or rule or regulation
What actions are deemed as misconduct in violation of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Willful disobedience, theft, habitual absence without leave, disorderliness, and habitual breach of any law or rule or regulation
What is the threshold for willful disobedience to be considered misconduct under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The exact threshold for willful disobedience may not be clearly defined in the Act, but it is generally understood that repeated instances of disobedience or refusal to follow lawful instructions can amount to misconduct.

A micro-enterprise with 10 employees in the garment industry has an employee named Afsar who has been absent from work for three consecutive days without permission. The management has sent a formal reminder to Afsar, but he failed to report to duty on the fourth day. What act is considered as misconduct under this situation?
Habitual absence without leave. According to Section 24(4) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, habitual absence without leave is treated as a misconduct act.

A small-scale manufacturing company with 50 employees in the food processing industry has an employee named Ali who has been found drinking alcohol during work hours. When questioned by management, Ali denied any wrongdoing but was later caught on camera consuming liquor from his phone. What act is considered as misconduct under this situation?

Disorderliness and willful disobedience. According to Section 24(4) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, disorderliness and willful disobedience are treated as misconduct acts. In this scenario, Ali's actions demonstrate both disorderliness (drinking alcohol during work hours) and willful disobedience (denying wrongdoing when questioned).
What happens to a worker who is acquitted on an appeal after being dismissed under section 23(1)(a)?

He shall be reinstated to his original post or shall be appointed to a suitable new post; and if any of them is not possible, he shall be paid compensation at a rate equal to the rate of compensation payable to a discharged worker, deducting the amount of compensation already paid to him for his dismissal. (Section 23(5))
What happens to a worker who is acquitted on appeal and had been terminated under section 23(1)(a)?

A worker was dismissed under section 23(1)(a) but was later acquitted on appeal. What is his next course of action?

He shall be reinstated to his original post or shall be appointed to a suitable new post; and if any of them is not possible, he shall be paid compensation at a rate equal to the rate of compensation payable to a discharged worker, deducting the amount of compensation already paid to him for his dismissal.
If an employee was dismissed under section 23(1)(a) and acquitted on appeal, what entitlements does he retain?

He shall be reinstated to his original post or shall be appointed to a suitable new post; and if any of them is not possible, he shall be paid compensation at a rate equal to the rate of compensation payable to a discharged worker, deducting the amount of compensation already paid to him for his dismissal.
What if the worker is not available to resume his original post?

He shall be appointed to a suitable new post. What happens after the suspension period is over, and the enquiry into the misconduct charge concludes?

After the 60-day suspension period is over, the enquiry into the misconduct charge will be concluded. The employee will then be summoned to appear before the management for a hearing, where a decision on whether to terminate their employment or take disciplinary action will be made.
Can an employer unilaterally extend the suspension period beyond 60 days without obtaining approval from the Labour Department or a higher authority?

No, an employer cannot unilaterally extend the suspension period beyond 60 days. According to Bangladesh Labour Law, any extension of the suspension period must be approved by the Labour Department or a higher authority, and such approval must be obtained before extending the period.

A manager at a medium-sized manufacturing company (100 employees) in Dhaka has temporarily suspended an employee for 30 days pending an enquiry into allegations of theft. However, the employee's union representative claims that this suspension is not in accordance with the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. What should the HR manager do?

The HR manager should immediately review the labour laws and regulations regarding suspension of employees pending enquiry into misconduct charges. According to 2006, the minimum period of suspension allowed for a worker charged with misconduct is 60 days. The HR manager should extend the temporary suspension to 60 days as per the law, ensure that the employee receives their full wages during this period, and initiate a fair enquiry into the allegations.

A small retail shop in Chittagong has temporarily suspended an employee for one month due to poor performance. However, the employee was also on maternity leave under the Bangladesh maternity Leave and Child Care Act 2013. What are the HR manager's obligations?

The HR manager should first consider the provisions of the Bangladesh maternity Leave and Child Care Act 2013, which requires employers to maintain the salary and benefits of pregnant employees for six months after childbirth. What happens if the employer fails to pay a worker's final payment of dues within the specified 30 days?
If the employer fails to make the payment within 30 days, the worker can file a complaint with the Labour Department or seek compensation from the court.
Can an employee still receive their final payment of dues if they have already left Bangladesh and returned to another country?
Yes, as per section 20 of the Act, the payment is due upon cessation of employment, regardless of the worker's location or citizenship.

A manufacturing company with 50 employees in the textile industry has an employee who resigns after working for 5 years. The employee is entitled to a total of Tk. 500,000 as final payment of dues, including salary and provident fund. How should the HR department proceed to ensure compliance with the Bangladesh Labour Act?

The HR department must calculate the employee's final payment within 30 working days following the date of cessation of employment (as per section 20 of the Bangladesh Labour Act). They should also provide the necessary documents, such as the employee's work record and provident fund contribution details. Additionally, they should ensure that the payment is made in cash or through a bank transfer to prevent any delays or disputes.

A small IT company with 20 employees in Dhaka has an employee who quits their job after working for only 6 months. The employee's salary and benefits were not paid on time, resulting in an outstanding amount of Tk. 150,000. How should the HR department handle this situation to avoid any legal repercussions?

The HR department must first verify if the company has made all necessary payments to the employee within the specified timeframe (as per section 20 of the Bangladesh Labour Act). If not, they should pay the outstanding amount immediately and provide a written confirmation of payment. They may also want to consider paying an additional Tk. 10,000 as interest on the delayed payment, as per the Bangladesh Labour Act's provisions for late payments.
In what circumstances can an employer employ a retiring worker under contract, as per section 26(4)?
If it is decided by the authority and in accordance with the service rules of the establishment.

If it is decided by the authority and in accordance with the service rules of the establishment.
What are the specific circumstances that allow an employer to engage a retired worker on a contract basis?
If it is decided by the authority and in accordance with the service rules of the establishment.
When can an employer hire a retiring employee under a contract, according to section 26(4) of the Bangladesh Labour Act?
If it is decided by the authority and in accordance with the service rules of the establishment.

The employer should ensure that the decision is made in accordance with the service rules of the establishment and obtained approval from the relevant authorities, such as the labour department or a competent court. The employer must also provide adequate notice to the retiree, considering their seniority and length of service, and comply with any necessary provisions under section 26(4) of the Bangladesh Labour Act.
What happens to a worker who does not vacate their residential accommodation within the specified period of 60 days from the date of cessation of employment?

The employer may make a complaint against him to the Labour Court, and if found guilty, may be directed by the Court to vacate the accommodation within a reasonable time, or the police officer may be informed to evict the worker by force.
Can the employer also claim compensation for the worker's occupation of the accommodation, considering it was done in violation of Bangladesh Labour Law?

Yes, the employer may claim compensation under 2006, which states that an employee shall be entitled to receive compensation from his employer in certain circumstances, including occupation of residential accommodation without permission.
What is considered a 'reasonable time' for the worker to vacate the accommodation as per the court's direction?

A reasonable time would depend on various factors such as the length of tenancy, the worker's personal circumstances, and the availability of alternative accommodation. The Labour Court may consider these factors when determining a reasonable time frame for the worker to vacate the premises.

A manufacturing company with 50 employees has a policy of housing its workers in a hostel. However, one employee, Mr. X, who is a union leader, refuses to vacate the hostel accommodation after his employment contract ended 60 days ago. The company wants to evict him but is concerned about potential labor unrest. What are the legal implications for the company and how should they proceed?

The company has the right to make a complaint against Mr. X to the Labour Court, as per the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018). The court may direct Mr. X to vacate the accommodation within a reasonable time frame. To mitigate potential labor unrest, the company should engage with the union and other affected employees to find an amicable solution. This could involve offering alternative accommodation or financial compensation to Mr. X. Failure to comply with the court's order may result in further action being taken against the company.
What is the required procedure for a worker to file a complaint under section 33 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Any worker must send their complaint in writing to their employer, by registered post, within 30 (thirty) days of being informed of the cause of such complaint.
What is the timeframe for a worker to file a complaint under section 33 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Any worker must send their complaint in writing to their employer, by registered post, within 30 (thirty) days of being informed of the cause of such complaint.
How does a worker initiate a complaint under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 regarding workplace grievances?
Any worker must send their complaint in writing to their employer, by registered post, within 30 (thirty) days of being informed of the cause of such complaint.

Any worker must send their complaint in writing to their employer, by registered post, within 30 (thirty) days of being informed of the cause of such complaint.
Can a worker file a complaint to the Labour Department directly if they have already sent their complaint to the employer?

No, once a complaint is filed with the employer, the worker cannot file it with the Labour Department. The Labour Department will not entertain any complaints that were previously sent to the employer.
Is there any time limit for the employer to respond to and resolve the complaint after receiving it from the worker?
Yes, under 2006, the employer must respond to the complaint within 30 (thirty) days and resolve it in accordance with the provisions of the Act.

A large IT company in Dhaka, employing over 500 employees, has been facing a situation where some employees have been working overtime without receiving their overtime pay. The HR department should immediately inform all affected employees of the cause of the issue (overtime work without payment) in writing, by registered post, within 30 days as per section 33 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. The HR department should also review the company's overtime policy and ensure that it is up-to-date and compliant with the law. Additionally, the HR department should consider revising the policy to provide timely payment for overtime work, to prevent any potential complaints under section 33.
What entitlements are reserved for tea industry workers regarding retirement benefits, as per section 26(4)?

Existing retirement benefits, including other benefits, shall be applicable to tea industry workers.

There are no further specified entitlements or conditions mentioned for tea industry workers regarding retirement benefits; the provision primarily highlights the applicability of existing benefits.

The company should also review its retirement benefit obligations and start making necessary arrangements to pay existing retirement benefits to eligible employees before the closure.

Are there any specific dimensions or strength requirements for the ropes that must be applied to hoists and lifts?
Yes, the Bangladesh Labour Act requires that the ropes should have a minimum diameter of 16 mm and a breaking load of at least 1.5 times the maximum safe working load.
Do these additional rope requirements apply only to new installations or also to reconstruction or renovation work?

The additional rope requirements apply to both new installations and reconstruction or renovation work, where hoists and lifts are installed or reconstructed after the commencement of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006.

A medium-sized construction company (with 50 employees) is installing a new hoist system in its rooftop warehouse. The existing cage is dependent on rope and chain, and the company needs to reconstruct it after the commencement of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006. What additional requirements must be applied to the hoist system?

At least 2 (two) ropes should be applied to the hoist system. This is in line with Section 37 (4) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, which states that at least two ropes shall be used for hoists and lifts where the cage is dependent on rope or chain.

A manufacturing company with 500 employees, operating in the textile industry, has a revolving vessel used to transport raw materials. The vessel is required to operate at a speed of 10 km/h by law. However, due to inadequate training and lack of safety measures, the operator often exceeds this safe working speed. What measures should be taken by the company to ensure compliance with the Bangladesh Labour Act?

The company should provide regular training sessions for the operators on the safe operating speed of the revolving vessel, emphasizing the importance of adhering to the prescribed speed limit. Additionally, they should conduct regular safety inspections and implement a system to monitor the operator's performance. Furthermore, the company should consider installing speed limiter devices or other safety measures to prevent excessive speeding. By taking these measures, the company can ensure compliance with the Bangladesh Labour Act and maintain a safe working environment for its employees.

A small-scale garment factory with 200 employees is using a fly-wheel driven by power to transport heavy luggage. During a recent inspection, it was found that the speed of the fly-wheel was exceeding the prescribed limit, posing a risk to the employees' safety. What should be done by the management to address this issue?

The factory management should immediately stop the operation of the fly-wheel until the necessary repairs and modifications are made to ensure compliance with the Bangladesh Labour Act. They should also provide training to the employees on the safe operating procedures of the fly-wheel, emphasizing the importance of adhering to the prescribed speed limit. Furthermore, the management should conduct a thorough safety audit to identify any potential risks and implement measures to prevent similar incidents in the future.

Yes, as per section (d) of Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006
Can an employer also install cameras for monitoring purposes in common areas like restrooms, medical rooms and dining hall?
Yes, as per Section 35 of Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, an employer can install CCTV cameras to monitor areas including restrooms, medical rooms, and dining halls.
Are there any specific guidelines or regulations regarding the placement and use of close circuit cameras in the factory, especially in relation to worker privacy?

Yes, as per Section 35 of Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, the employer should ensure that the installation of CCTV cameras does not infringe on workers' right to privacy and that the footage is stored securely and only accessed by authorized personnel.

What are the specific circumstances under which the Government may appoint a competent person to hold an enquiry into cases of accident or disease?

The HR manager should immediately notify the employer about the order and advise on a possible appeal process within 10 days (1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018). A worker at a construction site in Dhaka, employed by Mian Construction Company (a small business with 20 employees), suffers a work-related injury. The HR manager should immediately notify the Labour Inspectorate about the incident and provide details of the injury. The HR manager should also inform the worker's family members about their rights under the workers' compensation policy. Additionally, the HR manager may want to explore options for providing compensation to the injured worker or arranging for medical treatment through a government-funded program.
If an employee informs the employer about a dangerous building or machinery, what is the consequence for the employer if they fail to take appropriate measures?
The employer shall be liable to pay compensation to the worker so injured at double the rate of compensation payable under Chapter VII
What happens to an employer who fails to address a safety concern reported by an employee about hazardous building conditions?
The employer shall be liable to pay compensation to the worker so injured at double the rate of compensation payable under Chapter VII
If an employee reports a workplace hazard, what is the potential penalty for the employer if they don't take corrective action?
The employer shall be liable to pay compensation to the worker so injured at double the rate of compensation payable under Chapter VII
What are the consequences for an employer who ignores an employee's warning about a hazardous work environment, as mandated by the Bangladesh Labour Act?
The employer shall be liable to pay compensation to the worker so injured at double the rate of compensation payable under Chapter VII

The worker informs the management that the staircase is not safe and poses a risk to his life. Rohan may be entitled to compensation at double the rate of compensation payable under Chapter VII of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. The employer must take immediate action to rectify the staircase condition and provide a safe working environment for all employees.

What is the ratio of first-aid box or cupboard to workers that an establishment must provide, as per the Labour Act?
One for every 150 workers ordinarily employed in the establishment

One for every 150 workers ordinarily employed in the establishment
How many workers should an establishment provide with access to a first-aid facility, according to the Labour Act of Bangladesh?
One for every 150 workers ordinarily employed in the establishment
What is the mandatory provision for workplace safety and health as per the amended Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 regarding first aid facilities?
One for every 150 workers ordinarily employed in the establishment

A medium-sized IT company with 500 employees in Dhaka is planning to expand its operations and hire an additional 200 workers. How many first-aid boxes or cupboards must the establishment provide, as per the Labour Act?

Based on the ratio of one first-aid box or cupboard for every 150 workers ordinarily employed in the establishment, the IT company should provide at least 3 first-aid boxes or cupboards (500 + 200 = 700 workers). However, since this is an expansion and not a new initial setup, only the additional 200 workers require consideration. Therefore, the company must provide one additional first-aid box or cupboard for every 150 workers in the newly hired employees. In this case, it should provide at least 1 first-aid box or cupboard for 100 new hires (200/150 = 1.33), which means at least one more, but practically, it would be better to have an additional second box as a precaution.

A small manufacturing company with only 50 employees in a remote area of Bangladesh has been operating for years without any employee injuries. However, due to recent changes in the Labour Act, they are now required to provide first-aid boxes or cupboards. How many must they provide?

Based on the ratio of one first-aid box or cupboard for every 150 workers ordinarily employed in the establishment, the small manufacturing company with 50 employees must provide at least 1/150 = 0.0067 (rounded up to the nearest whole number) boxes. However, considering the remote location and limited employee population, providing only one box might not be practical or sufficient. It would be advisable for the company to consider having a minimum of two first-aid boxes or cupboards, as the risk of injuries is lower in this scenario but still exists.
In case an employee is injured due to use of a building or machinery that was reported as dangerous, what is the liability of the employer?
The employer shall be liable to pay compensation to the worker so injured at double the rate of compensation payable under Chapter VII

A manufacturing company with 100 employees, producing textiles in a small workshop. One of the employees, Mr. Islam, is injured while operating an old machine that was not properly maintained by the management. The incident occurred on the first day of employment for Mr. Islam. What should be done?

The employer should immediately report the incident to the Labour Inspectorate and provide medical treatment to the injured employee. Since it was reported as dangerous, the employer's liability is at double rate of compensation. The company must also conduct a thorough investigation into the cause of the accident and take necessary safety measures to prevent similar incidents in the future.

The employer had been warned about the safety risks several times but did not take adequate measures to mitigate them. What are the employer's responsibilities?

The employer has a duty to provide a safe working environment and must ensure that all necessary safety precautions are in place, even if they have been previously warned about the risks. The employer should also provide compensation to Ms. Rahman at double the rate of compensation payable under Chapter VII. Additionally, the company may face disciplinary action for negligence and failure to comply with Labour Law regulations.
What is the process for an employer to appeal against a labour inspector's order if they object to it?
The employer must inform the Government in writing, stating their objection and reasons within 20 days of receipt of the order

The HR department should inform the government in writing within 20 days of receiving the order, stating their objection and reasons. They should also consider the potential impact on employees' safety and well-being, as well as the company's long-term sustainability. The response should be professional, objective, and focused on finding a solution that balances business needs with labour regulations. Furthermore, the HR department may want to consult with other stakeholders, such as senior management or trade unions (if present), to ensure that all perspectives are considered.

A large construction company in Bangladesh has 500 employees working on a high-rise building project in Chittagong. Additionally, the HR department may want to investigate the cause of the wage delay and take necessary measures to prevent similar incidents in the future, such as reviewing the payroll system or employee contracts.
Who is responsible for maintaining a first-aid treatment facility in an establishment with more than 300 workers?
A person trained in first-aid treatment, available during all working hours of the establishment
Who determines the person trained in first-aid treatment?
The establishment must ensure that a person trained in first-aid treatment is appointed and present during all working hours of the establishment, (1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006.
What are the responsibilities of the person trained in first-aid treatment?

The person trained in first-aid treatment is responsible for maintaining a first-aid treatment facility and providing basic life support and care to employees during emergencies, (2) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006.

The HR department must identify a trained person in first-aid treatment who will be available during all working hours of the establishment. This individual may already work for the company or can be hired from outside, provided they meet the necessary training and availability requirements.
