The HR department should also maintain records of the employee's leave request, medical certificate, and any relevant communication with the employee.
What is the purpose of the fund established by the Government under Section (1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The fund is established to transfer undistributed money deposited with it for the welfare of workers.
What type of establishments are required to deposit money with the fund?
All factories, workshops, and other establishments employing 10 or more persons are required to deposit money with the fund.
How is the deposited money used by the fund?
The deposited money is transferred to the fund to support various welfare activities for workers such as old age pension, medical treatment, disability pension, etc.

A medium-sized manufacturing company (50 employees) in the textile industry wants to establish an employee welfare fund. If the company has a surplus amount of Tk. 500,000 in its current savings account which is undistributed and not utilized for any purpose, as per Section (1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, what action should the management take?
The company should deposit the Tk. 500,000 in the fund established under Section (1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 to transfer it for the welfare of its workers.

An IT outsourcing firm with over 100 employees has a provision of Tk. 150,000 for employee welfare and benefits which is yet to be utilized due to various reasons. As per the provisions of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018), what will happen to this remaining amount?
2006, the company should deposit the Tk. 150,000 in the fund established under Section (1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 to transfer it for the welfare of its workers.
How will the Labour Court distribute compensation paid to a dependent in case of a deceased worker's death, as per Section (9) of the Act?
The Labour Court may apportion the compensation among the dependents of the deceased worker or allot it to any one dependent in such proportion as they think fit.
What is the method by which a Labour Court determines the distribution of compensation to dependents in case of a deceased worker's death?
The Labour Court may apportion the compensation among the dependents of the deceased worker or allot it to any one dependent in such proportion as they think fit.
How does a Labour Court decide on the allocation of compensation paid to dependents after a worker's death?
The Labour Court may apportion the compensation among the dependents of the deceased worker or allot it to any one dependent in such proportion as they think fit.
What discretion does a Labour Court have when distributing compensation to dependents in cases of work-related fatalities?
The Labour Court may apportion the compensation among the dependents of the deceased worker or allot it to any one dependent in such proportion as they think fit.
What happens if the Labour Court decides to allot the compensation to one dependent only?

If the Labour Court decides to allot the compensation to one dependent only, it must provide a written explanation for this decision and justify the distribution based on the specific circumstances of the case.
Can the Labour Court change its decision regarding compensation allocation if new evidence comes to light after the initial judgement?
Yes, under Section 9(2) of the Act, the Labour Court can modify or overturn its earlier decision if new evidence is presented that was not available during the original hearing.

A manufacturing company with 500 employees, employing workers in the garment industry, has a new policy of mandatory overtime without consent. An employee, Mr. X, is required to work for 12 hours straight on two consecutive days without rest. After three months, Mr. X dies due to overwork-related fatigue. The Labour Court is informed about the company's actions. How would you advise the HR department in this case?

Under Section 67 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, the employer is liable for any injury or death caused by the employee's employment. In this scenario, it can be argued that the employer's policy of mandatory overtime without consent led to Mr. X's untimely death. The HR department should initiate an internal investigation and gather evidence to support their case. They may also need to provide medical certification from a government hospital to prove the causal link between overwork and death. It is recommended that the HR department reports this incident to the Directorate General of Factories and Works (DGFW) and files a complaint with the Labour Court, seeking compensation for Mr. X's dependents under Section 9 of the Act.

A company in Bangladesh has 100 employees, mostly female, who work as sewing machine operators in their factory. One of these female workers, Ms. Y, suffers a hand injury while working with sharp objects and is dismissed from her job due to the nature of her injury. However, under the company's new policy, the injured worker would have been eligible for compensation only after six months of continuous employment. Ms. Y had worked at the factory for less than three months when she suffered the injury. How should the HR department handle this situation?

Under 2006, an employer is required to provide medical compensation to employees who suffer injuries during their employment. In this scenario, Ms. Y was dismissed from her job due to a work-related injury that occurred within the first three months of her employment. The HR department should file a complaint with the DGFW and seek approval for an immediate payment of medical compensation of the Act. It is also recommended that the HR department reports this incident to the Labour Court, seeking compensation for Ms. Y's dependents under Section 9 of the Act, as per the provisions regarding apportionment of compensation in case of a deceased worker's death.
What is the maximum period within which a claim for compensation must be preferred before it can be considered by the Labour Court, as per Section (2) of the Act?
The claim must be preferred within 2 (two) years of the occurrence of the accident or within 2 (two) years of the date of death.
What is the time frame within which a worker must file a claim for compensation after an accident in Bangladesh, as per the Labour Act?
The claim must be preferred within 2 (two) years of the occurrence of the accident.
How much time does a claimant have to submit a case to the Labour Court in Bangladesh regarding workplace accidents or deaths?
The claim must be preferred within 2 (two) years of the occurrence of the accident or within 2 (two) years of the date of death.
What is the deadline for filing a compensation claim with the Labour Court in Bangladesh, as per the Labour Act?
The claim must be preferred within 2 (two) years of the occurrence of the accident or within 2 (two) years of the date of death.
What happens if the employee fails to file a claim within the specified time frame?

If an employee fails to file a claim within the 2-year time limit, they may still be able to file a revised claim or appeal against the Labour Court's decision, but it may affect their chances of receiving compensation.
Are there any exceptions to this 2-year time limit for filing a claim?

Yes, under certain circumstances such as pregnancy-related illnesses, maternity leave, or if the employee was a minor when the accident occurred, the time limit can be extended. However, these exceptions are subject to specific requirements and procedures under the Labour Act.

Rahul, a 30-year-old production supervisor at a garment factory with 500 employees, is injured in an accident while operating a machine. The incident occurred on March 10th, and Rahul's colleagues report that he has been experiencing severe back pain since then. The company has provided basic first aid but not formally reported the incident to the Labour Department. Can Rahul file a claim for compensation within the legal timeframe?

Yes, Rahul can file a claim for compensation as he was injured on March 10th. However, it is essential that the factory reports the incident to the Labour Department and provides a detailed account of the accident, including the date, time, and nature of the injury, within the required timeframe.

Amit, a 40-year-old manager at a construction company with 1000 employees, passes away suddenly due to cardiac arrest on August 25th. Amit's family claims that he had been experiencing health issues for several months prior to his death. The Labour Department has issued a warning notice to the company for violating labour laws, including not providing adequate medical facilities and not conducting regular health check-ups. What are the implications of this incident on the company?

The family can file a claim for compensation within 2 years of Amit's date of death (August 25th). The Labour Department's warning notice indicates that the company has been non-compliant with labour laws, including not providing adequate medical facilities and conducting regular health check-ups. This incident may lead to further investigations and potential penalties or fines against the company for its failure to comply with labour regulations.
Can a dependent's claim for compensation be set off against any other claim, and what is the reason behind this prohibition as per Section (156) of the Act?
No, a dependent's claim cannot be set off against any other claim. This is because the Act prohibits assigning, attaching, or charging compensation to any person other than the worker.

What should be done by the Labour Court in case it varies an order under Section (13) of the Act due to negligence of a parent to heir their children, as per Section (14) of the Act?

The Labour Court may make such order for the variation of its former order as they think fit in the circumstances of the case, provided that such person has been given an opportunity of showing cause against the order.
What happens if the Labour Court fails to give an opportunity of showing cause against the order?
If the Labour Court fails to give an opportunity of showing cause against the order, it may be considered as a violation of natural justice and can be challenged in higher courts.
Can the Labour Court impose any penalty on the parent for not providing maintenance to their children?

Yes, the Labour Court can impose penalties such as monetary compensation or even imprisonment if the parent has committed a serious breach of duty towards their children, depending on the severity of the case.

A mid-sized manufacturing company (50-100 employees) in the textile industry has a policy of not providing maternity leave to female employees. The Labour Court orders the company to provide one month of paid maternity leave to an employee, Ayeeda, who is going through her first pregnancy. However, the company's management claims that this order varies from their existing labour practices. What should be done by the HR department in this situation?

The HR department should ensure that the company complies with the Labour Court's order and provides Ayeeda with one month of paid maternity leave. This may involve updating the employee handbook, providing necessary training to management staff, and making necessary arrangements for covering the employee's responsibilities during her leave. The HR department should also communicate the updated policy and procedure to all employees and provide support to those who may be affected by this change.

A large construction company (100+ employees) in Dhaka has an informal agreement with its migrant workers, who are employed on a contract basis. The workers have been working long hours for several months without any paid leave or benefits. When one of the workers falls ill due to exhaustion and is unable to perform his duties, the management refuses to provide medical leave or compensation. What should be done by the HR department in this situation?

The HR department should investigate the company's labour practices and ensure compliance with the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. This may involve consulting with the Labour Department, reviewing the contract agreements with migrant workers, and providing necessary training to management staff on the provisions of the Act. The HR department should also provide medical leave and compensation to the affected worker and take steps to prevent similar situations from arising in the future.
What is the applicable date for determining an accident in case of disablement caused by a disease?
The first day of the continuous absence of the worker
What is the date used to determine an accident when an employee suffers disablement due to illness?
The first day of the continuous absence of the worker
For determining an accident in cases of disease-related disability, what specific date applies?
The first day of the continuous absence of the worker
In Bangladesh Labour Law, on which date is an accident determined when a worker suffers permanent disablement due to illness?
The first day of the continuous absence of the worker
If a worker suffers from an occupational disease and is absent for more than one day, which date will be considered as the first day of continuous absence?

The last day of absence will be considered as the first day of continuous absence. No, in such cases, the applicable date for determining an accident may be different and should be determined on a case-by-case basis.

A small-scale garment factory with 50 employees in Dhaka is facing a sudden outbreak of dengue fever among its workforce. One employee, Rashed, has been absent for the last 7 days due to fever and is diagnosed with dengue fever after undergoing medical tests. According to Bangladesh Labour Law, what is the applicable date for determining an accident in case of disablement caused by a disease?

The first day of the continuous absence of the worker, which in this case would be 7 days from the date of onset of symptoms, making it 7th February (first day of continuous absence) as the applicable date.

A large multinational pharmaceutical company with over 500 employees in Chittagong has a long-serving employee, Ahmed, who is on medical leave for the last 30 days due to occupational exposure to hazardous chemicals. The employer is considering terminating Ahmed's employment contract as per the Bangladesh Labour Act. According to Section 64 of the Act, what is the condition that must be fulfilled by the employer before terminating Ahmed's employment?

The employer must give a notice of at least two weeks to the employee before termination, and in this case, since Ahmed has been on medical leave for more than 30 days, the employer should have already given him the required notice. However, the key issue here is that the labour court can order reinstatement if the reason for the layoff or retrenchment was not genuinely due to business reasons, but due to an act of God or a natural calamity.
Can a Labour Court consider and decide a claim to compensation if the notice is not given or the claim is not preferred on time?
Yes, if the Court is satisfied that there was sufficient reason for the failure to give such notice or prefer such claim (Section 4)
What is the basis for a Labour Court to consider compensation claims made after the notice period?
If the Court is satisfied that there was sufficient reason for the failure to give such notice (Section 4)
Can an employee still file a claim with the Labour Court if they missed the deadline for filing their complaint?
Yes, if the Court is satisfied that there was sufficient reason for the failure to give such notice or prefer such claim (Section 4)
Is it possible for a Labour Court to entertain compensation claims that were filed late due to unforeseen circumstances?
Yes, if the Court is satisfied that there was sufficient reason for the failure to give such notice or prefer such claim (Section 4)
What does Section 4 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 state exactly?
states that if the Court is satisfied that there was sufficient reason for the failure to give such notice or prefer such claim, it can consider and decide a claim to compensation.
How will a Labour Court determine what constitutes 'sufficient reason' for failing to give notice or prefer a claim on time?

A Labour Court may take into account factors such as unforeseen circumstances, lack of written records, or administrative errors when determining whether there was sufficient reason for the failure to give notice or prefer a claim.

A small manufacturing company with 20 employees in the textile industry fails to give adequate notice to an employee before terminating their service. The employee has been with the company for over 10 years and is one of the senior staff members. What can be done by the HR department to address this situation?

The HR department should immediately notify the Labour Department within 7 days of termination, as per Section 2 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. Additionally, the HR department should initiate an internal inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the termination and provide compensation to the affected employee, considering their length of service and seniority. The company may also need to file a case for rectification with the Labour Court to address any irregularities in the notice period.

The company may be liable for compensation, even if they technically missed the filing deadline. Furthermore, the company may also face penalties and fines under Section 3 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. It is essential for the HR department to rectify this situation promptly by filing the required affidavit and providing a detailed explanation to the Labour Court.
How should a notice under Section 150 be served, and what information must it contain?

In this scenario, the employer may be liable to compensate Mr. X under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, as the accident occurred during work hours and the employer's negligence was a contributing factor. The employee's injury will likely result in compensation payable.
What happens if an application for payment of compensation under a scheme referred to in section (6) is made within one month from the date on which the said certificate of the Government was given?
Proceedings under this Chapter may be commenced within 1 month from the date on which the said certificate of the Government was given
What is the time frame for initiating proceedings under this Chapter after receiving a Government certificate?
Proceedings under this Chapter may be commenced within 1 month from the date on which the said certificate of the Government was given
Can legal action be taken against an employer if an application for compensation is filed within one month of receiving a government-issued certificate?
Proceedings under this Chapter may be commenced within 1 month from the date on which the said certificate of the Government was given

What is the time frame for filing an application under section (6) of the Bangladesh Labour Act?
The application should be filed within one month from the date on which the said certificate of the Government was given.
Are there any additional requirements or documentation needed to file an application under section (6) of the Bangladesh Labour Act?
No specific requirements are mentioned, but it is assumed that the relevant documents and certificates as referred to in section (6) must be attached with the application.

A worker at a textile factory with 500 employees, in Dhaka, Bangladesh, has been injured on the job and is seeking compensation under the scheme as per section 6 of the Bangladesh Labour Act. The worker files an application for payment of compensation within one month from the date on which they received their certificate from the Government. What can the HR department do?

The HR department can initiate proceedings under Chapter V of the Bangladesh Labour Act, as specified in Section 7(1)(a) of the Act. This allows the employee to receive compensation for their injury within a time frame of one month after receiving the certificate from the Government.

A small-scale manufacturing company with only 20 employees in Sylhet, Bangladesh, has been involved in a dispute with an employee who was terminated without proper notice. The employee claims unfair termination and seeks compensation under the scheme as per section 6 of the Bangladesh Labour Act. The company received their certificate from the Government one month ago. What are the implications for the company?

Given that the employee has filed an application within one month from the date on which they received their certificate, the company may face legal repercussions for non-compliance with Chapter V of the Bangladesh Labour Act. The HR department should take immediate action to rectify the situation and initiate proceedings (1)(b) of the Act to prevent any potential penalties or fines.
What is the effect of an agreement made before or after the commencement of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, whereby a worker relinquishes any right to compensation?
Such agreement shall be void to such extent as to remove or reduce the liability of any person to pay compensation under this Chapter
What is the validity of an agreement where a worker agrees to relinquish compensation rights, regardless of when it was made in relation to the Bangladesh Labour Act's commencement?
Such agreement shall be void to such extent as to remove or reduce the liability of any person to pay compensation under this Chapter
Can a pre-commencement employment contract that releases an employee from compensation claims be declared invalid by law?
Such agreement shall be void to such extent as to remove or reduce the liability of any person to pay compensation under this Chapter
How does Bangladesh Labour Law treat agreements made prior to the 2006 Act that exempt an employee from claiming compensation?
Such agreement shall be void to such extent as to remove or reduce the liability of any person to pay compensation under this Chapter
Can a worker relinquish their right to compensation under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 if they are under 18 years old?
No, as the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 specifically prohibits any agreement that would affect the rights of minors.
Does a valid agreement made before the commencement of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 still apply to the extent that it affects compensation liability?
Yes, such agreements are still enforceable under the law prior to its commencement, but any subsequent amendments or changes due to the Act will override those pre-existing agreements.

A small-scale textile factory with 20 employees, in a collective bargaining agreement signed in 2015 before the commencement of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, agrees to relinquish any right to compensation in case of dismissal. The factory is inspected and found to be violating health and safety standards, resulting in the death of an employee. The government is asked to pay compensation under the Labour Act. Is the agreement valid?

The agreement is void to the extent that removes or reduces the liability of the employer to pay compensation under Chapter 7 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 regarding occupational accidents and injuries. However, since the agreement was signed before the commencement of the Labour Act, it may not be entirely void, but its provisions on relinquishing compensation rights would only be applicable after the Labour Act came into effect.

A large IT outsourcing company in Bangladesh with over 500 employees has a policy requiring employees to sign an 'employment agreement' before joining. The agreement includes a clause stating that in case of dismissal, the employee will receive a limited amount of notice pay and no further compensation. When an employee is dismissed after a disciplinary hearing due to health concerns, claiming unfair dismissal, how would this provision be affected by the Labour Act?

The 'employment agreement' provision regarding notice pay upon dismissal would still be applicable as it was signed before the commencement of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. However, any provisions that reduce or remove the liability to pay compensation under Chapter 7 of the Labour Act for unfair dismissal due to occupational accidents and injuries (in this case, health concerns) could be deemed void to such an extent as to reduce the employer's liability. The employee would likely be entitled to a fair wage, adequate notice period, and possibly additional compensation for unjust termination.
What is the purpose of a return that must be sent by every person employing workers, as directed by the Government?
To send a correct return specifying the number of injuries in respect of which compensation was paid by the employer during the previous year and the amount of such compensation
What is the purpose of the annual return that employers must submit to the Government?
To report on the number of work-related injuries and compensation paid by the employer during the previous year
How does an employer comply with the law by submitting a return to the Government?
By providing accurate information on the number of injuries for which compensation was awarded, as well as the amount of compensation paid, in their annual return
What is the main objective behind the submission of an annual return by every employer in Bangladesh?
To facilitate the government's monitoring and reporting of workplace accidents and injuries, ensuring compliance with labour laws and regulations
Shahin, the HR Manager of a company with 100 employees in a textile manufacturing factory, is required to send a return to the Government. What does Shahin need to include in his return?

Shahin needs to include the number of injuries that occurred in his factory during the previous year and the amount of compensation paid by the employer to the injured workers. He must specify this information for each injury, including the date of occurrence and the worker's identity.

Aklia, a newly appointed HR Manager at a company with 500 employees in the construction industry, receives a notice from the Department of Labour requiring her to send a return. What is Aklia's responsibility regarding this notice?

Aklia must ensure that she sends the required return to the Government within the specified deadline. This includes providing accurate information about compensation paid for injuries or deaths resulting from work accidents in the previous year, including the number of incidents and the corresponding compensation amounts.
What is the procedure for registering an agreement under Section 170 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
A memorandum of such an agreement must be sent to the Labour Court by the employer, and the Court shall record it in a register if satisfied with its genuineness.
What is the timeline for filing a memorandum of agreement under Section 170 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The timeframe is not specified in the Act, but it should be filed as soon as possible after the agreement is made.
Can an employee also file a memorandum of agreement with the Labour Court if they have entered into such an agreement with their employer?
No, only the employer can file a memorandum of agreement under Section 170; however, employees may be required to disclose the existence of such agreements when asked.

A small-scale garment factory with 500 employees in Dhaka is planning to implement a new performance-based promotion scheme for its production staff. The employer wants to offer a higher wage and bonus to the top performers, but it needs approval from the Labour Court under Section 170 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. What are the necessary steps the factory must take before submitting the agreement to the court?

The garment factory should prepare a clear written agreement outlining the terms and conditions of the performance-based promotion scheme. The employer should then send a memorandum of this agreement to the Labour Court in Dhaka, along with all relevant supporting documents. Once the Memorandum is received by the Court, it will record the agreement in its register if satisfied with its genuineness.
In case of a fatal accident, what is the power of the Labour Court to require more deposit from the employer?

The Labour Court may call upon the employer to show cause as to why they should not make a further deposit within a specified time, and if they fail, the Court may determine compensation and require the employer to deposit the deficiency.
What is the Labour Court's power in case of a fatal accident, and how does it relate to employer deposits?

The Labour Court may call upon the employer to show cause as to why they should not make a further deposit within a specified time, and if they fail, the Court may determine compensation and require the employer to deposit the deficiency.
In the event of a fatal accident, what is the procedure for the Labour Court to recover additional deposits from an employer?

The Labour Court may call upon the employer to show cause as to why they should not make a further deposit within a specified time, and if they fail, the Court may determine compensation and require the employer to deposit the deficiency.
Can the Labour Court compel an employer to pay additional deposits in the event of a fatal accident?

Yes, The Labour Court may call upon the employer to show cause as to why they should not make a further deposit within a specified time, and if they fail, the Court may determine compensation and require the employer to deposit the deficiency.
In what circumstances can the Labour Court determine compensation if an employer fails to show cause and make a further deposit?

The Labour Court may determine compensation in cases where the employer has sufficient resources or assets to settle the claim, but chooses not to, or where the accident was caused by gross negligence or willful default.
Can the employer be required to pay compensation immediately, even if they make a further deposit, and what are the implications for their credit score?

Yes, the Labour Court may order immediate payment of compensation if it is deemed that the employer has sufficient resources to settle the claim. This can have significant implications for the employer's credit score and financial reputation, potentially affecting their ability to secure loans or attract investors.

A medium-sized textile factory with 200 employees in Bangladesh is involved in a fatal accident where two workers lose their lives. The employer claims that they have already fulfilled all their labour obligations under the Labour Act. However, the Labour Court receives complaints from the deceased workers' families about unpaid wages and non-payment of benefits. What steps should the HR manager take to address these concerns?

The HR manager should immediately notify the labour department and file an complaint with the Labour Court. The employer should provide detailed records of payment to employees, including wages and benefits paid prior to the accident. The HR manager should also prepare evidence to support the claim that all labour obligations have been fulfilled, such as attendance records, pay slips, and any relevant documentation. It is recommended that the HR manager seeks advice from a lawyer specializing in Labour Law to ensure compliance with all requirements.

A small construction company in Bangladesh has 50 employees and has been involved in several fatal accidents in the past year. The employer has been ordered by the Labour Court to deposit Rs. 5 million as compensation for previous accidents. However, the employer claims that they are facing financial difficulties due to increased competition in the market and have requested a further extension of time to pay the additional deposit. What is the power of the Labour Court in this situation?

The Labour Court may call upon the employer to show cause as to why they should not make a further deposit within a specified time, which would allow them to assess whether the employer's request for an extension is reasonable. If the employer fails to provide sufficient explanation or justification for their request, the Court may determine compensation and require the employer to deposit the deficiency. In this case, the Labour Court may consider factors such as the employer's financial situation, the severity of the accident, and any previous compliance with labour obligations when making its decision.
What is the condition under which an application for settlement of any matter by a Labour Court can be made?

No application can be made unless both parties have failed to settle the question raised as to such matter by agreement, except in cases where the worker himself suffers losses or a dependent makes the application.
What is the prerequisite for filing an application to settle a dispute with a Labour Court?
Both parties must have failed to reach an agreement on the matter, unless the worker or their dependent makes a case due to losses incurred
Under what circumstances can an employee file an application with the Labour Court to resolve a labour dispute?
An application can be made when both parties have failed to settle the issue through agreement, except in cases where the worker suffers losses or their dependent makes the application
What is the condition for initiating proceedings before a Labour Court to resolve a labour-related issue?
Both parties must have exhausted all attempts at resolving the matter through negotiation, unless an exception applies due to financial loss suffered by the worker or their dependent
In what circumstances can a worker file an application with the Labour Court even if both parties have not reached an agreement?

If the worker himself suffers losses or a dependent makes the application. Can a labour dispute be referred to the Labour Court without the consent of both the employer and the employee, and if so under what conditions?

No, a labour dispute cannot be referred to the Labour Court without the consent of both parties. However, the court may intervene in cases where the worker suffers losses or a dependent makes the application.

A small-scale textile factory with 50 employees faces a dispute between management and a group of 10 workers who are demanding overtime pay for working on Sundays. What is the first step HR should take in this situation to resolve the matter?

Since both parties have failed to settle the question by agreement, the HR should ensure that the dispute is documented and then file an application with the Labour Court under 2006, as no overtime pay has been provided to the workers despite their demands.

A large multinational company operating in Bangladesh has a contract worker who has been working for over two years. The worker has recently suffered a serious illness and is currently receiving medical treatment. The company is refusing to provide the worker with a settlement amount as per the Labour Court's ruling on settlements in similar cases. What should HR do?

Given that the worker himself suffers losses, HR can file an application with the Labour Court under 2006 on behalf of the contract worker for a settlement amount. This is because the worker has suffered financial losses due to his illness and is unable to work, making it necessary to approach the court for a fair settlement.
What is the venue of proceedings for matters under Section 167 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The same shall be done by or before the Labour Court having jurisdiction in the area where the accident took place, unless the worker is a master of a ship or a seaman, in which case it shall be done by or before the Labour Court having jurisdiction in the area where the owner or agent resides or carries on business.
Where is the venue of proceedings for accidents specified under Section 167 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, determined by the type of work involved?
The same shall be done by or before the Labour Court having jurisdiction in the area where the accident took place.
What is the primary consideration for determining the venue of proceedings under Section 167 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, particularly for seamen?
The worker's master or agent resides or carries on business
In what circumstances does the venue of proceedings for accidents under Section 167 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 deviate from the area where the accident occurred?
For seamen, it shall be done by or before the Labour Court having jurisdiction in the area where the owner or agent resides or carries on business.
What is the significance of determining the venue of proceedings under Section 167 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

Determining the venue of proceedings ensures that disputes are resolved in a timely and efficient manner, taking into account the location where the accident or incident took place, which may affect the parties involved.
How does this provision impact workers who are seamen or masters of ships, particularly when it comes to filing complaints or claims?

This provision allows these individuals to file their complaints or claims in the Labour Court where the ship's owner or agent resides or carries on business, providing them with a more accessible and convenient option for resolving disputes related to maritime accidents.

A small manufacturing company with 50 employees in the textile industry has an accident that results in a worker's injury. The Labour Court having jurisdiction in the area where the accident took place is in Dhaka. What are the implications for the company?

Since the Labour Court having jurisdiction in the area where the accident took place (Dhaka) is also applicable to a small manufacturing company with 50 employees, they must file the proceeding under 2006 by or before this court. The company should ensure compliance with all relevant labour laws and regulations regarding worker safety, compensation, and social security.

A multinational IT company in Bangladesh has a remote worker who is injured while working from home due to equipment failure. The remote worker is not an employee of the company but rather an independent contractor. What are the obligations of the company under Section 167 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

Since the labour court having jurisdiction in the area where the owner or agent resides or carries on business (i.e., Dhaka) applies to this scenario, the multinational IT company must file the proceeding by or before this court. Although the worker is an independent contractor, the company may still be held liable under 2006 for ensuring the safety and well-being of their contractors, particularly if they are carrying on business in that area.
Can a civil court have jurisdiction to settle any question required to be settled by a Labour Court under Section 166 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
No, no civil Court shall have jurisdiction to settle any question which is by or under this Chapter required to be settled by the Labour Court.

What type of disputes or cases can never be referred to a civil court, but must instead be handled by a Labour Court as mandated by Section 166 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Any question required to be settled by a Labour Court under this Chapter
Can a civil court have jurisdiction to settle disputes that fall under the scope of Section 166 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 but are not specifically listed in Chapter X?
No, as per Section 170 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, only matters mentioned in Chapter X shall be referred to a Labour Court.
If a case is already pending before a Labour Court under Section 166 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, can it be transferred to a civil court?
Yes, but only with the consent of both parties or as per an order of the Labour Court itself. However, this decision should be made in accordance with Section 170 of the Act.

A small-scale manufacturing company with 10 employees in the textile industry is facing a labour dispute between an employee and management over unpaid wages. Can the dispute be taken to a civil court instead of a Labour Court?

No, according to 2006, no civil court shall have jurisdiction to settle any question which is by or under Chapter VII (labour disputes) required to be settled by the Labour Court. The dispute should be taken to the Labour Court for resolution.

A large multinational company operating in Bangladesh with over 500 employees, including several foreign nationals, has been accused of discrimination against local employees. Can this case be handled by a civil court or does it need to be referred to the Labour Court?

Yes, 2006, no civil court shall have jurisdiction to settle any question which is by or under Chapter VII required to be settled by the Labour Court. The case should be referred to the Labour Court for fair and impartial resolution.
What happens if an agreement for payment of compensation is not registered under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The employer shall be liable to pay the full amount of compensation payable by him under this Chapter, and he shall not be entitled to deduct more than half of any amount paid to the worker by way of compensation.
Does the non-registration of an agreement for payment of compensation affect other benefits or entitlements that the worker may be entitled to under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

Yes, it can. The lack of registration may impact the worker's eligibility for other benefits, such as reinstatement, re-employment, or retirement benefits, and may also affect the employer's liability for other forms of compensation.
Can the worker still claim compensation if the agreement was registered under the Bangladesh Companies Act 1994?

No, according to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, an agreement for payment of compensation must be registered under this Act. Registration under the Companies Act 1994 is not sufficient to satisfy the requirements of the Labour Act.

A micro-enterprise with only 5 employees in the textile industry enters into an agreement with one of its workers for payment of compensation upon termination. The agreement does not specify the amount or terms of compensation, and it is not registered under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006.

The employer would be liable to pay the full amount of compensation payable by him under Chapter IV of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. However, since the agreement was not registered, the employer cannot deduct more than half of the amount paid as a deduction for administrative expenses. The worker is entitled to receive the full amount of compensation, and the employer should ensure that it is paid within the specified timeframe.

A large multinational company operating in Bangladesh has an employee who suffers a work-related injury and is eligible for compensation under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. The company offers a lump sum payment to settle the claim, but the employee refuses and insists on receiving medical treatment and rehabilitation as per Chapter IV of the Act.

In this scenario, the employer would be liable to pay the full amount of compensation payable by him under Chapter IV of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. Since the employee refused the lump sum payment, the company cannot deduct more than half of the amount paid from the total compensation. The employer should ensure that the employee receives medical treatment and rehabilitation as per the provisions of the Act and pay the remaining compensation within the specified timeframe.
What is the requirement for an appeal to lie against an order of a Labour Court under Section 172(1)(a)?
A substantial question of law must be involved in the appeal, and the amount in dispute in the appeal must not be less than 1,000 (one thousand) taka.
How does the Labour Court determine what constitutes a substantial question of law?

A substantial question of law is determined by considering whether the appeal raises an issue that affects the substantive rights or obligations of a party, such as issues related to statutory interpretation, jurisdiction, or procedural matters.
Are there any additional requirements for the amount in dispute beyond the minimum threshold of 1,000 taka?
Yes, if the amount in dispute is less than 1,000 taka, the appeal must be filed by a party who has secured an award from a Labour Court and the amount in dispute exceeds 1,000 taka.

A multinational IT company operating in Bangladesh with 500 employees has a labour dispute between an employee and the management over unfair termination. The employee claims that they were unfairly dismissed without sufficient reason. What is the HR's position on filing an appeal against the Labour Court's order?

The HR should carefully evaluate whether a substantial question of law is involved in the appeal, considering the circumstances of the case. If so, and given that the amount in dispute is likely to be significant (potentially exceeding 1,000 taka), it would be prudent for the HR to consider filing an appeal against the Labour Court's order.

A small textile factory in Dhaka with 20 employees faces a situation where one of its long-serving employees claims that their wages are not paid on time. The employee demands payment of arrears for the past three months. What is the HR's approach to handling this situation?

In this scenario, the HR should follow the standard procedures for paying wages and addressing employee grievances. However, considering the relatively small amount of dispute (likely less than 1,000 taka) and the small number of employees involved, it may not be necessary or worthwhile for the HR to file an appeal against a potential order from the Labour Court.
What is the period of limitation for an appeal under Section 172(5)?
The period of limitation for an appeal under this section shall be 60 (sixty) days.
What happens if the appeal is not submitted within the 60-day period?
If an appeal is not submitted within the 60-day period, it will be considered as withdrawn and the decision of the labour court or tribunal will be final.
Does the 60-day period start from the date of judgment or from the date of service of the notice?
The 60-day period starts from the date of receipt of the notice of judgment, not from the date of judgment itself.

The company has received the complaint from the Joint Council of Workers (JOC), but the employee, Mr. X, has not filed a complaint within the prescribed time limit under Section 172(5). The HR department should verify the compliance of the notice period with the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 and then communicate to the employee, Mr. X, about the non-compliance and provide him an opportunity to rectify the situation. The company claims that it had sent the payment to the bank on time, but due to technical issues with the bank's system, the payments were delayed. They should also communicate with Mr. Y and try to resolve the issue amicably by offering him a compromise on his wages or allowances. Can a Labour Court withhold a deposit paid to it under Section 173 only if the employer chooses to appeal under Section 172(1)(a)?
Yes, where the employer prefers an appeal under Section 172(1)(a), and if the Tribunal so directs, it shall surely be withheld.

The HR Manager should immediately inform the management about the situation and advise them to seek professional legal advice on how to proceed with the appeal. What is the condition for transferring money deposited with a Labour Court to another country, as per Section 174?

What happens if an officer's term of office exceeds 3 years, and can it be extended?

According to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, if an officer's term of office exceeds 3 years without approval from the Appropriate Government or Ministry concerned, they may not serve beyond that period. However, in exceptional circumstances, the government may extend their tenure with prior approval.
How does this provision apply to officers elected by workers or representatives under collective bargaining agreements?

This provision applies to officers elected by workers or representatives under collective bargaining agreements as well. In such cases, their term of office would also be limited to 3 years unless the agreement provides for a different tenure period.

A small garment factory with 100 employees in Dhaka is facing an election cycle. The company has 5 officers, including the Managing Director and 4 department heads. How long can these officers serve, considering the Bangladesh Labour Act?

The term of office for officers in a group of establishments cannot exceed 3 years. Since this garment factory has multiple departments headed by different officers, each officer's term is capped at 3 years, but they may be re-elected to the same position in subsequent cycles.

A large textile mill with over 500 employees across two locations in Bangladesh is undergoing restructuring. As part of this process, 2 senior managers are being considered for promotion to Group General Manager positions. However, their current contracts specify a term of 5 years. Under the Bangladesh Labour Act, can these promotions be approved?

No, under the Bangladesh Labour Act, the term of office for officers in a group of establishments cannot exceed 3 years. Although the senior managers have existing contracts, their promotion would require approval from the relevant authorities to ensure compliance with the 3-year limit. Existing contracts may need to be renegotiated or terminated to accommodate the new appointments.

According to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, what constitutes grounds for the dissolution of a trade union?

What is the process for formally dissolving a trade union under the amended Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The procedure for dissolution involves passing a resolution either by the general members or by the Central Committee, although detailed formalities are not explicitly specified in the Act.
What are the grounds for dissolution of a trade union under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The Act does not explicitly state the grounds for dissolution, but it can be assumed that it would be done in cases where the trade union's activities become illegal or its objectives are no longer aligned with national interests.
Can a trade union be dissolved without following the prescribed procedures if it is deemed to be detrimental to the public interest?

While there is no specific provision for such situations, the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 relies on general principles of natural justice and the rule of law. Therefore, dissolution without proper procedure would likely be subject to judicial review or intervention.

A manufacturing company with 500 employees in Bangladesh has a dispute between the management and the trade union representing its workers. The trade union threatens to go on strike unless their demands are met. What can the management do under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The management should engage in dialogue with the trade union and attempt to resolve the dispute through negotiation, as stated in Section 26 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. If the dispute cannot be resolved through negotiation, the employer may request the Ministry of Labour and Employment to appoint an arbitrator or mediator to assist in resolving the dispute.

A small garment factory with 150 employees in Dhaka has a member who is also a union leader of another trade union. The management suspects that this employee is using their position to influence decisions that benefit other unions and cause unrest among its own workers. What are the implications under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The factory management should address the issue by discussing it with the suspected employee and seeking clarification on their role and responsibilities, as stated in Section 17(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. If the employee is found to be engaging in activities that conflict with their duties, the employer may take disciplinary action against them, up to and including termination of employment, of the Act.

A new employee, Mr. X, joins a company with 50 employees in the textile industry. During his onboarding process, he requests to bring his family members, including his wife and two children, who are unemployed. The HR department needs to decide how many family members can be employed under the provisions of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006.

According to 2006, a worker is entitled to bring up to one child under the age of 18 years to work in the same establishment. In this case, only Mr. X's one child can be employed under the provisions of the act.

A company with 100 employees in the IT sector wants to lay off 20 employees due to restructuring. However, during the notice period, it discovers that one of the laid-off employees, Ms. Y, is pregnant and has been working for over two years with excellent performance. The HR department needs to decide how many weeks' worth of wages should be paid to Ms. Y as per the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006.

According to Section 25B of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, an employee who is laid off during a notice period and has been employed for at least two years is entitled to receive one month's worth of wages for each year of service, plus any accrued leave. In this case, Ms. Y should be paid four weeks' worth of wages (two years x one month per year) as per the provisions of the act.

No, the proposal is not allowed as it would be considered an unauthorized reduction of wages, which must follow the procedures outlined in 2006, including giving prior notice to the employees and obtaining their consent.

What is the process for electing representatives to a trade union if there are less than 20 workers?

In cases where there are less than 20 workers, the members can elect their representatives directly. However, the establishment must ensure that at least one-third of the total workforce is present for the election to be valid.
Can a trade union with fewer than 20% membership still negotiate with the employer on behalf of its members?

Yes, although it may have limited bargaining power. The labour act does not explicitly prohibit it from doing so. However, if an employer refuses to recognize or negotiate with a union that represents less than 20% of the workforce, it may be considered unfair labour practice.
A small apparel factory with 50 workers, located in Dhaka, wants to form a trade union. How many employees must they get to register under the labour act?

To be entitled for registration, the minimum membership required is 20% of the total number of workers employed. Therefore, 50 * 0.2 = 10 workers must join the factory's proposed trade union before it can apply for registration.

A textile mill with 200 employees in Chattogram has 30 employees who are on strike due to unpaid wages and poor working conditions. What implications does this have on the establishment's obligation to form a trade union?

The striking employees' participation in the proposed trade union might indirectly support the registration of the union. However, if the striking workers do not meet the 20% requirement, the factory must still register the union if at least 40 of the total 200 employees join voluntarily or are recruited by the union. The situation remains unclear until the actual number of joining members is confirmed.

A medium-sized textile manufacturing company with 500 employees in Dhaka has two trade unions already registered. Can the company register more than three trade unions?

No, according to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018), no more than three trade unions can be registered at any time in an establishment or group of establishments. The existing two trade unions are likely recognized by the labour department and the new registration request will be rejected.

A small service provider with only 20 employees in Chittagong has one trade union already registered. If the company is considering merging with a larger company, can it register more than three trade unions?

The labour department will likely recognize all existing trade unions affiliated to the new parent company, including the employee-led union from the smaller service provider. Therefore, if the merger proceeds, the total number of registered trade unions may exceed three, but only those that are recognized by the labour department will be allowed to represent employees in collective bargaining.
Under what circumstances may a dispute regarding whether two or more establishments are under the same employer be referred to the Director General for settlement?

When there is doubt or dispute as to whether two or more establishments are under the same employer, or whether they are allied to and connected with one another for the purpose of carrying out the same industry

A small textile mill with 50 employees is operating under the name of ABC Ltd. Meanwhile, a separate manufacturing unit in Dhaka with 200 employees is also operating under the same name, ABC Ltd. The employees at both units have been claiming separate wages and benefits from their respective managers. What should HR do to resolve this dispute?

HR should investigate the situation by verifying the ownership structure of both establishments, checking for any contractual agreements between the two units, and ensuring that all employee records are up-to-date with the relevant authorities. If necessary, HR can refer the dispute to the Director General for settlement if there is doubt or dispute as to whether both establishments are under the same employer.

A multinational company has a single office in Dhaka with 100 employees, which handles all its Bangladeshi operations. However, the company also owns two separate factories, one in Chattogram and another in Chittagong, which employ around 500 workers each. The employees at both factories are claiming payment of wages in compliance with Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. What should HR do to resolve this dispute?

HR should confirm whether the two factories are allied to and connected with the single office in Dhaka for the purpose of carrying out the same industry. If they are, then the employees at both factories may be considered under the same employer, and HR should ensure that wages and benefits are paid as per the Labour Act. However, if there is doubt or dispute regarding the connection between the factories and the office, HR can refer the dispute to the Director General for settlement.
What is the time limit for the Director General to register a trade union after receiving an application?
Within 55 (fifty five) days from the date of receipt of the application
What is the timeframe within which the Director General must register a trade union following receipt of an application?
Within 55 (fifty five) days from the date of receipt of the application
How long does the Director General have to process and approve a trade union registration request after receiving it?
Within 55 (fifty five) days from the date of receipt of the application
What is the maximum duration allowed for the Director General to complete the registration process for a newly submitted trade union application?
Within 55 (fifty five) days from the date of receipt of the application
What happens if the Director General fails to register a trade union within the specified time limit?
The employer may be liable for non-compliance with the Labour Act, and the applicant may have the right to appeal against the decision.
Can the Director General extend the time limit for registering a trade union in exceptional circumstances, such as during election periods or natural disasters?
Yes, under the Director General may, on an application, extend the time limit by a period not exceeding 30 days.

A manufacturing company with 250 employees, operating in the textile industry, receives an application from a group of workers to form a trade union. The Director General has not registered the new trade union yet due to lack of awareness about the necessary documents and procedures. What should be the HR manager's priority?

The HR manager should provide the necessary information and guidance to the workers regarding the registration process, document requirements, and timelines, ensuring they submit their application within 55 days as per the Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018). Meanwhile, the HR manager can also facilitate the submission of applications by preparing the required documents and taking them to the relevant authorities.

A small-scale retail shop with 50 employees faces a dispute between two groups of workers - one group wants to form a trade union, while another group opposes it. The Director General has already issued a notice to register the new trade union within 55 days. How should the HR manager handle this situation?

The HR manager should remain neutral and facilitate an open discussion between both groups of workers to understand their concerns and grievances. The HR manager can also help arrange a meeting with the Director General, enabling the formation of a consensus among the workers about forming or not forming a trade union. If necessary, the HR manager can provide guidance on the procedures for registration and submission of applications within the specified time frame.
A trade union has applied for registration but the Director General finds it deficient in material respect. How long does the trade union have to reply to the objection?
Within a period of 15 (fifteen) days from the receipt of the objection
Will the trade union be allowed to re-register if they provide a revised application after expiry of the 15-day response period?
Yes, but it is recommended that the trade union should respond within the given time frame and submit a complete and accurate application
What are the consequences if the trade union fails to reply or respond to the objection within the specified timeframe?
The trade union may be considered as unregistered, and they will not be allowed to participate in collective bargaining or representation of employees until the registration is approved

A manufacturing company with 500 employees in the textile industry has a dispute between a group of employees who are dissatisfied with their overtime pay. The employees claim that they are not receiving fair compensation for their extra work hours, while management claims that the current policy is in line with the Labour Act. What should HR do in this situation?

HR should facilitate a meeting between the employees and management to discuss the issue and provide guidance on the Labour Act's provisions regarding overtime pay. The company should also review its policies and procedures to ensure compliance with the law. Additionally, HR may want to consider providing training for employees on their entitlements and the process for reporting grievances.

A small-scale shop owner has a single employee who works as an apprentice. The apprentice is requesting a day off to attend a vocational training program, but the employer is hesitant due to concerns about lost productivity. What obligations does the employer have under the Labour Act?

The employer has a duty of care towards the apprentice and must allow them to take time off for the vocational training program, as required by the Labour Act. The employer may need to adjust their production schedule or make alternative arrangements to ensure that work is covered during the apprentice's absence. Additionally, the employer should provide the apprentice with written confirmation of their entitlement to attend the training program and must not deduct any wages due to the employee's absence for this purpose.
What is considered a 'group of establishments' for the purpose of forming a trade union under Section 183?
All establishments in a specified area carrying on the same specified industry where more than 20 (twenty) workers are employed

All establishments in a specified area carrying on the same specified industry where more than 20 (twenty) workers are employed

All establishments in a specified area carrying on the same specified industry where more than 20 (twenty) workers are employed

All establishments in a specified area carrying on the same specified industry where more than 20 (twenty) workers are employed
What is the specific area that can be considered for a group of establishments under Section 183?
A specified area can include a city, town, or village, as designated by the relevant government authority.
Are there any exceptions to the requirement of more than 20 workers employed in the same industry within a specified area to form a trade union?
Yes, if less than 20 workers are employed, they can still form a trade union if they belong to the same industry and have similar working conditions.

A company with 25 employees in the textile industry has factories in two different locations. One factory has 10 workers, and the other has 15 workers. Can a trade union be formed for all the workers of this company?

No, a trade union can only be formed for the 5 workers who are employed at both factories, since they meet the condition of being in the same specified industry (textile) but not exceeding 20 workers.

What is the timeframe for appealing a rejected trade union registration application in Bangladesh under the Labour Act?
The trade union can prefer an appeal to the Labour Court within 30 (thirty) days from the date of rejection or the expiry of the 55-day period, whichever is earlier

The trade union can prefer an appeal to the Labour Court within 30 (thirty) days from the date of rejection or the expiry of the 55-day period, whichever is earlier
What is the procedure for filing an appeal to the Labour Court?

The trade union must submit its appeal to the Registrar of the Labour Court along with all relevant documents, such as the application for registration, the order of rejection, and any supporting evidence.
Can the labour court review the decision of the Director General on its own merit without an appeal from the trade union?
No, the Labour Court can only hear the case if it has been referred by the trade union or another party. However, in exceptional circumstances, a complaint can be filed directly to the Labour Court.

A factory with 50 employees, operating a textile manufacturing unit in Dhaka city, has recently appointed a new management team. What is the correct course of action for the employee union?

The employee union should file an appeal to the Labour Court within 30 days from the date of notification or the expiry of the 55-day period, whichever is earlier, citing relevant provisions of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 and the Industrial Relations Ordinance 1947. The union should also provide evidence of its registration, membership, and past negotiations with the management to support its claim for recognition.

A small IT company in Chittagong has recently hired a foreign contractor to work on a project for six months. The contractor claims that it is entitled to 100% foreign exchange remittance for its salary, despite the Bangladesh government's policy of withholding 10% of foreign contractor wages as a non-refundable tax. What is the correct course of action for the IT company?

The IT company should refer the matter to the Director General of Labour or the relevant labour inspectorate within 15 days of receipt of the contractor's claim. The company should also provide evidence of its compliance with the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 and the relevant foreign exchange regulations. If necessary, the company can appeal to the Labour Court to settle the dispute of the Act.
What is the purpose of a Standard Operating Procedure in keeping with Section 183, as mentioned in Section 187?

Can you elaborate on what a Standard Operating Procedure is in the context of Bangladesh Labour Law?

A Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) refers to a documented process or set of guidelines that outlines how to perform specific tasks or duties within an organization, ensuring consistency and efficiency. In this case, it's related to trade union registration.
How does the registration of trade unions through a SOP impact the rights and responsibilities of employees under Bangladesh Labour Law?

The registration of trade unions through a SOP ensures transparency and accountability in the process. This has implications for employee rights, such as protection from unfair dismissal and the right to collective bargaining, which are governed by the Labour Act.

Can small-scale metal industries that are not exempt from the registration requirement still operate under the provisions of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The employer should also ensure that all existing employees are registered with the labour department within a specific timeframe (usually 30 days) from the date of registration. Failure to comply may result in further penalties and action.
Can a worker employed in an establishment included in a group of establishments be elected as an officer of the trade union formed by the workers in that group?
Yes, but only if the constitution of the trade union provides for it. The number of such persons shall not exceed one-fourth of the total number of officers in the union.

Yes, but only if the constitution of the trade union provides for it. The number of such persons shall not exceed one-fourth of the total number of officers in the union.
Are workers from member establishments entitled to hold positions within a group trade union, under the condition that their workplace is represented?
Yes, but only if the constitution of the trade union provides for it. The number of such persons shall not exceed one-fourth of the total number of officers in the union.
Can a worker from a constituent establishment within a group be elected as an officer of the group's trade union, assuming their workplace has voting rights?

Yes, but only if the constitution of the trade union provides for it and the number of such persons does not exceed one-fourth of the total number of officers in the union.
