The Labour Court grants permission to cancel the registration of the company's trade union due to alleged internal conflicts. Who can appeal against this decision?

The temporary worker who is misclassified as a full-time employee, as well as the company management and relevant government authorities, may file an appeal against the decision. However, only the affected temporary worker has a direct right to appeal, while the company management and government authorities may also have grounds for appeal based on concerns about the legality of the trade union's cancellation.
What is the condition for cancelling the registration of a trade union on the ground mentioned in sub-section (1) (e)?
An application must be submitted to the Labour Court within 3 (three) months of the occurrence of unfair labour practice by such trade union
What is the time frame for submitting an application to cancel a trade union's registration due to unfair labour practice?
An application must be submitted to the Labour Court within 3 (three) months of the occurrence of such unfair labour practice
Under what circumstances can the registration of a trade union be cancelled, and how much time is given for submitting an appeal?
The registration of a trade union can be cancelled if there has been an unfair labour practice, and an application to cancel must be submitted to the Labour Court within 3 months
What procedural requirement needs to be fulfilled by an employer or worker in case they wish to have a trade union's registration revoked?
An application must be submitted to the Labour Court within 3 (three) months of the occurrence of unfair labour practice by such trade union for its registration to be cancelled
What is considered as an unfair labour practice under section (1) (e) of the Bangladesh Labour Act?

Unfair labour practices may include, but are not limited to, obstruction of production, refusal to recognize the employer's right to appoint a management representative, and failure to pay minimum wages or benefits.
Can an employee file a complaint under section (1) (e) if they were unfairly treated by their own trade union?
No, an employee can only file a complaint under section (1) (e) against the trade union that committed the unfair labour practice, not the individual employee.

A small-scale manufacturing company with 20 employees in the textile industry has a trade union that has been engaged in regular industrial disputes. The management suspects that the trade union is involved in unfair labour practices such as intimidation and harassment of employees. What should be done by the management?

The management should not cancel the registration of the trade union without first submitting an application to the Labour Court within 3 months of the occurrence of these unfair labour practices. The company can document all evidence of the unfair labour practices, including employee testimonies and witness statements, and submit a formal complaint to the Labour Court.

A multinational corporation with over 500 employees in Bangladesh has recently made significant changes to its HR policies, which have affected the employment terms of some workers. The workers are dissatisfied with the changes and have started protesting outside the company's office. What is the next step for the company?

The company should engage a trade union representative to negotiate with the workers and facilitate dialogue between management and employees. If necessary, the company can also submit an application to the Labour Court within 3 months of the occurrence of these unfair labour practices (in this case, the changes to HR policies) to cancel the registration of any aggressive or violent union members who are obstructing business operations.
What is the consequence if a trade union does not function as a registered trade union?
It shall not function as a trade union, and no person shall collect any subscription for the fund of the trade union except enrollment fee for membership
What happens to a trade union that is not functioning as a registered entity?
It shall not function as a trade union, and no person shall collect any subscription for the fund of the trade union except enrollment fee for membership
If a trade union fails to adhere to its registered status, what are the repercussions?
It shall not function as a trade union, and no person shall collect any subscription for the fund of the trade union except enrollment fee for membership
What is the effect on a trade union that does not operate in accordance with its registered status?
It shall not function as a trade union, and no person shall collect any subscription for the fund of the trade union except enrollment fee for membership
What happens if the trade union has already collected subscription fees before it was found to be unregistered?
The collected subscription fees can be refunded to the members, but only after deducting a reasonable administrative fee. The refund must be made within a specified time frame as per the Labour Act.
Can a registered trade union still function and operate if it has an unregistered branch or office in the country?
No, a registered trade union is not allowed to have an unregistered branch or office. The entire organization must be registered with the relevant authorities.

A small manufacturing company with 50 employees in the textile industry is facing financial difficulties and decides to dissolve its trade union. However, a group of employees still wish to establish a new trade union, which they claim has the majority support. What should be done?

The company should not allow the formation of a new trade union if it can prove that the initial dissolution was lawful and in accordance with the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. If the new trade union claims majority support, the employer should provide evidence of the original union's dissolution and ensure that all employees are aware of their rights to form a new union. The case should be referred to the Labour Department for mediation and resolution.

A public sector hospital in Dhaka with 300 employees has been facing financial constraints and decides not to collect subscription fees for its employee welfare fund. However, employees are still required to contribute to the fund through their salaries. Is this a lawful situation?

No, it is not a lawful situation. According to Section 25A of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, no person shall collect any subscription for the fund of a trade union except an enrollment fee for membership. The hospital's decision to continue collecting subscription fees without offering membership benefits is a violation of this provision. The employer should be directed to stop collecting these fees and ensure that all employees are informed about their rights to form a new union or request a review of the current collective bargaining agreement.
Can a worker or employer be a member of more than one trade union at the same establishment?
No, workers and employers are entitled to enroll themselves as members of only one trade union at a time at the same establishment
Can a worker enroll in more than one trade union at their workplace simultaneously?
No, workers are entitled to enroll themselves as members of only one trade union at a time at the same establishment
Are there any restrictions on an employer joining multiple trade unions within the same factory?
Yes, employers are not allowed to be members of more than one trade union at the same establishment
Is it possible for both workers and employers to be part of different trade unions in the same workplace?
No, workers and employers are entitled to enroll themselves as members of only one trade union at a time at the same establishment
Can a worker or employer change their trade union affiliation if they are already a member of another union at the same establishment?
No, as per Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, once a worker/employer joins one trade union, they cannot join any other trade union at the same establishment without the consent of both parties.
What happens if an employer wants to appoint more than one trade union representative for their employees

According to Section 24 of Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, only one trade union can be recognized as the representative body for a particular establishment. However, two or more unions can jointly negotiate with management for collective bargaining.

A medium-sized IT company in Dhaka has 150 employees, with a diverse workforce comprising both men and women. A worker, Md. Nazmul, is interested in joining the existing trade union at his workplace, but he also wants to enroll as a member of another trade union that caters to workers in the same industry. What should HR do?

HR should inform Md. Nazmul that according to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018), employees are entitled to enroll themselves as members of only one trade union at a time at the same establishment. However, HR can help Md. Nazmul explore other trade unions in the industry that may align with his interests and values.

A large manufacturing factory in Chittagong has 500 employees, mostly migrant workers from Rangpur. The existing trade union at the factory is facing a leadership crisis, and the management is considering allowing both the existing trade union's representatives and new, rival candidates to join as members. What should HR do?

HR should advise the management that according to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018), workers are entitled to enroll themselves as members of only one trade union at a time at the same establishment. Therefore, HR should ensure that the existing trade union's representatives are not allowed to join as members while the rival candidates are also not allowed. This may require mediation and involvement from relevant labor department authorities.
What is the name of the body corporate that a trade union shall be, and what rights does it have?

A trade union shall be a body corporate by the name under which it is registered, and it shall have perpetual succession and a common seal, and shall have power to enter into contract and to acquire, hold and dispose of property, both movable and immovable.
What is the nature of a trade union in terms of its corporate identity, and what rights does it possess?

A trade union shall be a body corporate by the name under which it is registered, and it shall have perpetual succession and a common seal, and shall have power to enter into contract and to acquire, hold and dispose of property, both movable and immovable.
What are the characteristics that qualify a trade union as a body corporate, and what rights do these characteristics confer upon it?

A trade union shall be a body corporate by the name under which it is registered, and it shall have perpetual succession and a common seal, and shall have power to enter into contract and to acquire, hold and dispose of property, both movable and immovable.
What specific attributes does a trade union need to possess in order to be considered a body corporate, and what privileges does this status confer upon it?

A trade union shall be a body corporate by the name under which it is registered, and it shall have perpetual succession and a common seal, and shall have power to enter into contract and to acquire, hold and dispose of property, both movable and immovable.
What does perpetual succession mean for a trade union?
Perpetual succession means that the life of the trade union is not limited by any specific person or entity, and it continues to exist even after its founding members retire or pass away.
Does the common seal of a trade union have any special significance in Bangladesh Labour Law?
Yes, the common seal of a trade union serves as an official mark that authenticates its documents and decisions, providing a level of legitimacy and credibility to its operations.
A newly established textile factory with 200 employees in Dhaka needs to form a trade union. Which legal requirements must the employer meet before the formation of the trade union?

The employer must provide information about the terms and conditions of employment, wages, working hours, and any other relevant matters to the workers who wish to form a trade union. The employer must also ensure that the workers have at least 20% of their workforce for forming a trade union. Additionally, the employer must not discriminate or intimidate the workers who wish to form a trade union.

A company in Chittagong with 50 employees is facing financial difficulties and wants to terminate the services of a 10-year employee due to alleged misconduct. What rights does the employee have under Bangladesh Labour Law?

The employee has the right to be heard before termination of employment, as per Section 61 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018). The employer must provide a written notice of at least one month's salary and must follow the prescribed procedures for disciplinary action. However, the employer may also file an appeal against the employee if they dispute the allegations of misconduct.
Is an employer allowed to impose any condition in a contract of employment that restricts a worker's right to join or continue membership of a trade union?
No, an employer shall not impose any condition in a contract of employment restraining the right of the worker concerned to join a trade union or continue his membership of a trade union.
Can an employer include a clause in the employment contract that prevents a worker from joining or remaining part of a trade union?
No, an employer shall not impose any condition in a contract of employment restraining the right of the worker concerned to join a trade union or continue his membership of a trade union.
What conditions are prohibited in employment contracts regarding workers' rights to join or leave trade unions?
No, an employer shall not impose any condition in a contract of employment restraining the right of the worker concerned to join a trade union or continue his membership of a trade union.
Are there any restrictions on employers imposing conditions that limit workers' freedom to join or leave trade unions?
No, an employer shall not impose any condition in a contract of employment restraining the right of the worker concerned to join a trade union or continue his membership of a trade union.

In a small manufacturing company with 20 employees, the employer wants to restrict employee A's right to join a trade union. Employee A has been with the company for more than 5 years and is an active member of the Bangladesh Garment Workers Union. What should be done?

The employer should not impose any condition in the contract of employment restraining employee A's right to join or continue membership of the trade union. Instead, the employer can have an open discussion with employee A about their concerns and explore alternative solutions that balance the company's interests with employee rights.

A medium-sized IT company with over 50 employees wants to conduct a performance appraisal exercise for all employees, including those who are not union members. However, one of the non-union member employees, X, requests to be excluded from the exercise as he fears it may affect his union membership rights. What should the HR department do?

The HR department should inform the employer that they cannot exclude employee X from the performance appraisal exercise solely because he is a union member. The company can still conduct the performance appraisal, but ensure that all employees are treated equally and without discrimination. The HR department should also review the company's policies to ensure they comply with the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 and do not inadvertently restrict an employee's right to join or continue membership of a trade union.

What is the consequence for an employer who discriminates against a worker in regard to any employment, promotion, conditions of employment, or working conditions on the ground that such worker is, or is not, a member or officer of a trade union?
The employer shall be liable for unfair labour practice.
What is the penalty for an employer who treats a worker unfairly based on their membership in a trade union?
The employer shall be liable for unfair labour practice.
If an employer discriminates against a worker due to their affiliation with a trade union, what consequence can they face under the law?
The employer shall be liable for unfair labour practice.
What happens to an employer who refuses to hire or promotes a worker based on their membership status in a trade union?
The employer shall be liable for unfair labour practice.
What exactly constitutes unfair labour practice under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 defines unfair labour practice as any action taken by an employer that is detrimental to the rights of employees, including discrimination against a worker due to their membership or non-membership in a trade union.
Can an employee file a complaint directly with the labour department if they believe they have been discriminated against by their employer, or must they go through internal channels first?

An employee can file a complaint with the labour department directly if they believe they have been discriminated against by their employer. There is no requirement to go through internal channels first.

A small-scale manufacturing company in Dhaka with 20 employees is facing financial difficulties. The owner, Mr. Ahmed, decides to lay off 5 employees, including a union representative named Jamil, without following the formal notice period and severance pay procedures as per the Bangladesh Labour Act. What is the employer's liability in this situation?

The employer, Mr. Ahmed, shall be liable for unfair labour practice due to discrimination against Jamil on the ground that he is a union representative. The employer must provide a minimum notice period of 30 days and severance pay as per the Bangladesh Labour Act, regardless of financial difficulties.

A multinational IT company in Chittagong with over 100 employees implements a new technology policy that requires all employees to work on weekends. The union representatives of the employees express concerns about the impact on work-life balance and employee well-being. What action can be taken by the management?

The management should engage with the union representatives and explore alternative solutions that respect employee rights, such as flexible working hours or adjusted shifts. Failure to do so may lead to unfair labour practice claims against the employer due to discrimination on the ground that employees are members or officers of a trade union.
Can an employer transfer the Chairman, general secretary, organizing secretary, or treasurer of any trade union in contravention of section 187 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
No, an employer shall not transfer the Chairman, general secretary, organizing secretary, or treasurer of any trade union in contravention of the provisions of section 187.
Can an employer lawfully transfer the leaders of a trade union in contravention of section 187 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
No, an employer shall not transfer the Chairman, general secretary, organizing secretary, or treasurer of any trade union in contravention of the provisions of section 187.
Does the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 permit employers to transfer trade union leaders without following section 187's guidelines?
No, an employer shall not transfer the Chairman, general secretary, organizing secretary, or treasurer of any trade union in contravention of the provisions of section 187.
Under what circumstances can an employer legally reassign the leaders of a trade union as per section 187 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

An employer may legally transfer the Chairman, general secretary, organizing secretary, or treasurer of any trade union in accordance with the provisions of section 187 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006.

A medium-sized apparel factory with 500 employees is considering outsourcing its union activities to a third-party provider. The existing trade union has been in operation for over 10 years and has a significant following among the workers. However, the company wants to reduce costs by not having to bear any additional expenses related to union administration. Can the employer outsource union activities without permission from the Bangladesh Labour Board?

No, the employer cannot outsource union activities without permission from the Bangladesh Labour Board. According to section 187 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, an employer must obtain approval from the Labour Inspectorate Division before outsourcing any trade union activities. The employer must also ensure that the third-party provider is registered with the Registrar of Joint Stock Companies and Facilitators of Business Ventures under the Companies Act 1994.

A large construction company in Dhaka has 2,000 employees and is planning to promote a new employee as the general secretary of the site union. However, there are allegations that the current general secretary has been involved in corrupt practices and has lost the trust of the workers. Can the employer unilaterally transfer the general secretary and promote the new employee without giving any opportunity to the existing general secretary to defend himself?

No, the employer cannot unilaterally transfer or demote a union official without following the correct procedures as prescribed under section 187 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. The employer must give the general secretary an opportunity to explain his actions and respond to any allegations made against him before making any decision. If the allegations are found to be substantiated, the employer can then take necessary action to transfer or demote the official, but only after following the due process.
What is the standard procedure that the Government shall frame to enquire into unfair labour practice?
The Government shall frame Standard Operating Procedure in keeping with the provision of this section.
What does the term "Standard Operating Procedure" mean in this context?
A Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) is a detailed, written plan that outlines the steps to be taken in a specific situation, in this case, an inquiry into unfair labour practice.
Who has the authority to enforce the implementation of the SOP regarding fair labour practices?
The enforcement authority could be either the Labour Department under the Ministry of Labour and Employment or other designated authorities as per the regulations framed by the Government.

A medium-sized garment factory with 500 employees in Dhaka city has accused one of its workers, Rakesh, of theft. The worker has been suspended pending investigation. However, the HR team is unsure about how to proceed and what procedures to follow according to the Bangladesh Labour Act.

The company should follow the standard operating procedure (SOP) for investigating unfair labour practices, as mandated by the Bangladesh Labour Act. This SOP should include steps such as informing the worker of the allegations, providing them with an opportunity to respond, and conducting a fair investigation with witnesses and evidence. The company should also ensure that the worker is not subjected to any form of harassment or intimidation during this process.

A small IT firm in Chittagong has been asked by its union to provide a list of employees who have completed 5 years of service with the company, as per the Bangladesh Labour Act. However, one employee, Araf, has recently married and is now eligible for a no objection certificate (NOC) from the employer. The HR team is unsure if they need to include Araf in the list.

According to the Bangladesh Labour Act, an employee who has completed 5 years of service is entitled to receive benefits such as NOC. Since Araf has recently married and is now eligible for NOC, he should be included in the list of employees who have completed 5 years of service. The company should ensure that Araf receives his due benefits and process his request for NOC in a timely manner.
What activities are exempt from prohibition under Section 82(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Trade union activities that relate to any committee, negotiation, arbitration, mediation, or other proceedings under this Act, and the employer has been duly informed thereof.
What are the specific trade union activities that are exempt from prohibition under Section 82(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Trade union activities that relate to any committee, negotiation, arbitration, mediation, or other proceedings under this Act, and the employer has been duly informed thereof.
Can trade union activities be exempt from prohibition under Section 82(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006 if they relate to committee work, negotiations, or employee disputes?
Yes, trade union activities that relate to any committee, negotiation, arbitration, mediation, or other proceedings under this Act, and the employer has been duly informed thereof.

Trade union activities that relate to any committee, negotiation, arbitration, mediation, or other proceedings under this Act, and the employer has been duly informed thereof.

No, (1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, trade union activities that relate to any committee, negotiation, arbitration, mediation, or other proceedings under this Act, and the employer has been duly informed thereof. A Bangladeshi garment manufacturer with 200 employees is undergoing restructuring due to global market fluctuations. During this process, an employee approaches the HR department and expresses dissatisfaction with their severance package, which was negotiated by the management and union representatives. Can the HR manager informally discuss the employee's concerns without involving the employer or trade union?

Yes, (1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, trade union activities that relate to any committee, negotiation, arbitration, mediation, or other proceedings under this Act, and the employer has been duly informed thereof. Intimidation, undue impersonation, or bribery through the officer of that trade union or any other person acting on its behalf.

A micro-enterprise with 10 employees in the textile industry is facing financial difficulties. The union representatives, who are also part-time workers, threaten to go on strike if the management doesn't agree to a pay raise of 20% immediately. However, the company's financial records show that this would be unsustainable. What unfair practice by the trade union can be considered in this situation?

In this scenario, intimidation or undue impersonation by the union representatives can be considered unfair practices. The management should engage with the union representatives to discuss possible solutions, such as a phased pay raise or other benefits, rather than resorting to threats of strikes.
What is anti-trade union discrimination as defined in Section 196A(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
Discrimination by employers against workers during the process of trade union formation or registration, or during pendency of an application for registration.
What are the consequences for an employer found guilty of anti-trade union discrimination under Section 196A(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
The employer may be liable to pay compensation to the affected worker(s), and/or face disciplinary action, including termination of employment.
Can an employer refuse to register a trade union simply because it is affiliated with a particular political party or ideology, as anti-trade union discrimination under Section 196A(1)?
No, such refusal would be considered anti-trade union discrimination. The registration process should remain neutral and based solely on the trade union's compliance with the Act and its activities.

A large manufacturing company in Dhaka with over 500 employees is facing unionization efforts from its workers. The management has informed the workers that they will not be allowed to form a trade union or hold strikes during business hours. What is the correct course of action for the HR department?

The HR department should inform the employer that their actions are discriminatory and in violation of Section 196A(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006. The management's actions could be considered anti-trade union discrimination as it restricts the workers' right to form a trade union or engage in collective bargaining. The HR department should also encourage open dialogue between management and employees to address their grievances and find alternative solutions.

A small IT firm with 20 employees in Chittagong is facing an application for registration of a new trade union by its workers. However, the company's management has expressed concerns about the potential disruption to business operations during strike action and has refused to register the union. What are the implications of this decision for the employer?

The employer's refusal to register the trade union could lead to anti-trade union discrimination as it restricts the workers' right to form a trade union or engage in collective bargaining. The Bangladesh Labour Board may intervene and order registration, which could result in penalties and reputational damage. Furthermore, failure to register a registered trade union may be considered an offense under Section 196A(1) of the Act, and the employer may face legal consequences. The HR department should advise management to reconsider their decision and facilitate the registration process as per the law.
Can a trade union compel or attempt to compel a worker to pay or refrain from paying subscription fees to the fund of the trade union?

No, (3)(e) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, a trade union cannot use intimidation, coercion, pressure, threat, confinement, physical injury, disconnection of telephone, water, or power facilities, or any other means to compel a worker to pay or refrain from paying subscription fees.

A small manufacturing company in the garment industry with 500 employees is facing financial difficulties. The management threatens to dismiss employees who do not pay their monthly union subscription fees. Can a trade union compel these employees to pay?

No, (3)(e) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, the management's actions constitute coercion and intimidation, which is prohibited. The trade union must instead try alternative methods such as open communication and negotiation with the employees to settle any disputes related to subscription fees.
What is the standard operating procedure for enquiring into unfair labour practice as per Section 196A(4) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
The Government shall frame a Standard Operating Procedure in keeping with the provisions of this section.
What is the composition of the committee established under Section 196A(4) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?
The committee shall consist of three members - a President and two members, one representing the management and another representing the workers.
How long does the inquiry into unfair labour practice as per Section 196A(4) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006 take?

The employee claims to have been subjected to physical harassment by her supervisor. How should HR handle this situation?

HR should initiate an inquiry into the matter as per Section 196A(4) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, by following the Standard Operating Procedure framed by the Government. Gather evidence, interview witnesses, and provide a safe and comfortable environment for the employee to recount her experiences. The HR representative should also document all incidents and maintain confidentiality until the inquiry is complete.

A small IT company in Dhaka employs 20 staff members, mostly young professionals. An employee has been receiving inconsistent salary payments for the past two months, and management claims it's due to 'system errors'. The employee feels this is unfair labour practice. What should HR do?

HR should conduct an inquiry into the salary payment issue as per Section 196A(4) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006. Review company records, interview finance and HR personnel, and determine if there's any evidence to support management's claims about 'system errors'. If necessary, facilitate a meeting between the employee and management to discuss possible resolutions and provide guidance on the law regarding unfair labour practice.
Who can be held liable for a tortuous act done in contemplation or furtherance of an industrial dispute by an agent of a trade union?
An agent of the trade union, if it is proved that such agent acted without the knowledge of or contrary to the clear instructions of the executive committee of the trade union.
Who can be held liable for a tortuous act committed by an agent of a trade union in the course of an industrial dispute?
An agent of the trade union, if it is proved that such agent acted without the knowledge of or contrary to the clear instructions of the executive committee of the trade union.
In what circumstances can an individual who acts on behalf of a trade union be held liable for tortuous conduct during an industrial dispute?
An agent of the trade union, if it is proved that such agent acted without the knowledge of or contrary to the clear instructions of the executive committee of the trade union.
Who bears the liability for a wrongful act committed by a trade union representative during an industrial dispute?
An agent of the trade union, if it is proved that such agent acted without the knowledge of or contrary to the clear instructions of the executive committee of the trade union.

A small manufacturing company in Bangladesh with 20 employees has an employment agreement that is up for renewal. The employee union representative requests a higher wage increase than what the company can afford. If the company refuses, can it unilaterally terminate the agreement?

What is the effect of a Labour Court's decision in an appeal, as per Section 223(7) of the Labour Act 2006?

A decision of the Tribunal in an appeal in respect of an award shall be effective from the date of the award.

A decision of the Tribunal in an appeal in respect of an award shall be effective from the date of the award.

The owner, Mr. X, decides to downsize the workforce and inform 20% of the employees (10 employees) that their services are no longer required due to 'restructuring'. However, one of the affected employees, Ms. Y, has been a union leader for the past two years. What are the implications of this action on Mr. X's business under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

As per section 33 (1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, an employer must give one month's written notice to an employee before terminating their services. However, in cases where the employer intends to dismiss an employee due to 'restructuring', they must also provide a minimum two-week's written notice and obtain approval from the labour officer within three days of giving the notice. Furthermore, Mr. X is required to maintain a register of all employees, including the affected employee Ms. Y, (1) of the Act.

A multinational IT company operating in Bangladesh has 500 employees across its offices in Dhaka and Chittagong. The company plans to introduce a performance-based promotion policy for its employees. One of the employees, Mr. Z, who has been with the company for five years, is disappointed when he does not receive a promotion despite meeting the required criteria. He files a complaint with the Bangladesh Labour Board under section 60 of the Act, alleging that the company has failed to provide him with 'just and fair' wages as per the provisions of the Minimum Wage Act 2013. What are the implications of this action on Mr. Z's case?

Under 2006, an employee who files a complaint against an employer can seek interim relief from the labour court, including reinstatement to his original position or payment of wages in arrears. Additionally, the court may also order the employer to pay damages for any loss or injury suffered by the employee due to the employer's failure to provide 'just and fair' wages. The court may also direct the employer to submit a written explanation within 14 days as to why the employee was not granted promotion.
What is the minimum period of service required for a beneficiary to participate in the Funds?
No beneficiary without completing 6 (six) months of service in a company during a year of account shall participate in the Funds.

A small textile factory with 20 employees hires a new employee, X, for 6 months. The employee's contract is terminated due to restructuring. After 1 year from the date of termination, the employee X wants to claim benefits from the company's Provident Fund. Is X eligible?
No, since X has not completed 6 months of service in a company during the accounting period of 1 year, they are not eligible for participation in the funds.

A multinational IT company with 50 employees operates in Bangladesh. An employee, Y, completes 5 years of service and then resigns to pursue further education. After 3 years without rejoining the company, Y applies to claim their Provident Fund benefits. Is Y eligible?

Yes, since Y has completed 6 months of service within the accounting period of each year for 2 years (out of the last 5 years), they are eligible for participation in the funds, despite not having worked for 3 years without rejoining the company.

What happens to the rights of shareholders who initially acquired their shares through the conversion of the Participation Fund into ordinary equity capital regarding future corporate actions such as bonus and right-issues?
They retain the same rights as other shareholders in participating in future bonus and right-issues.
What constitutes the Participation Fund, and how does it relate to bonus and right-issues?

The Participation Fund is a reserve created by an industrial enterprise with a minimum of 10% of its paid-up capital. It can be used for various purposes, including acquiring shares in other companies or converting into ordinary equity capital. When the Participation Fund is converted into ordinary equity capital, it can lead to a change in the company's ownership structure and potentially affect future bonus and right-issues.
How does the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 regulate the distribution of bonuses and rights issues in cases where shares are acquired through conversion of the Participation Fund?

The act requires that employees who were employed during the period for which the Participation Fund was created be given preference in the acquisition of shares. Additionally, the company must ensure that the rights of existing shareholders are protected, and all other shareholders will participate in future bonus and right-issues on a proportionate basis.
What is the maximum percentage of paid-up capital that the Participation Fund can represent after conversion?

What is the upper limit of the Participation Fund's representation in relation to the paid-up capital after conversion?
25% of the paid-up capital or 50% of the additional capital, whichever is less.
How much of the paid-up capital can the Participation Fund represent after a company has converted its shares?
The maximum percentage that the Participation Fund can represent is 25% of the paid-up capital or 50% of the additional capital, whichever is less.
What proportion of the total capital can be represented by the Participation Fund after a company's share conversion?
The Participation Fund cannot exceed 25% of the original paid-up capital or 50% of the newly added capital, whichever is smaller.
Can the Participation Fund represent more than 25% of the additional capital after conversion?
No, it cannot be more than 50% of the additional capital, whichever is less.
What happens to the Participation Fund if it exceeds the maximum limit of 25% or 50% of additional capital after conversion?
It will not be allowed and may be adjusted accordingly by the authorities, potentially requiring a revaluation of the company's structure.

Rahul, a 5-year employee of a medium-sized textile factory (50 employees) with average monthly salary of BDT 15,000, is dismissed without cause. How are the benefits of the Funds accrued to beneficiaries transferred when they are transferred to another office or unit?

The benefits of the Funds accrued to beneficiaries shall be transferred to the Funds of the office or unit to which they are so transferred, and their service in the previous office or unit shall be counted towards their entitlement to the benefits of the Funds of the office or unit to which they are so transferred.
How are the accrued benefits of an employee transferred when they move to a different office within the organization?

The benefits of the Funds accrued to beneficiaries shall be transferred to the Funds of the office or unit to which they are so transferred, and their service in the previous office or unit shall be counted towards their entitlement to the benefits of the Funds of the office or unit to which they are so transferred.
What happens to an employee's accrued benefits when they relocate to a new office or unit within the company?

The benefits of the Funds accrued to beneficiaries shall be transferred to the Funds of the office or unit to which they are so transferred, and their service in the previous office or unit shall be counted towards their entitlement to the benefits of the Funds of the office or unit to which they are so transferred.
How do employers handle the transfer of accrued benefits when an employee moves from one office to another within the organization?

The benefits of the Funds accrued to beneficiaries shall be transferred to the Funds of the office or unit to which they are so transferred, and their service in the previous office or unit shall be counted towards their entitlement to the benefits of the Funds of the office or unit to which they are so transferred.

The transfer of benefits may not be smooth due to lack of notice, which might affect the continuity of their service. The employer should ensure that the employee receives fair treatment and that their rights are protected.
Are there any specific procedures that need to be followed when transferring a beneficiary's benefits from one office or unit to another?

The exemptions generally apply to funds established under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018), but may not be applicable to other types of funds or schemes. It is recommended to consult the relevant provisions and seek clarification from tax authorities for specific guidance.

A private limited company with 10 employees in the textile industry has an Employees' Trust Fund (ETF) which accumulates a surplus of BDT 500,000. The company decides to distribute this amount as a one-time bonus to all employees. Is this distribution taxable as income?

What is the effect of the dissolution of the Dockworkers Management Board under section 263A of the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006?

What is the procedure for dealing with debts or liabilities incurred by dockworkers before their management board was dissolved?

The debts or liabilities incurred by dockworkers are deemed to have been incurred by the Chittagong Port Authority and Mongla Port Authority, respectively, after the dissolution of the management boards.

A mid-sized shipping company with 50 employees in the Dhaka office incurs a debt of BDT 500,000 to settle dues of their dockworkers. The dockworkers' management board was dissolved 6 months ago. What is the correct approach for the company?

The company should submit a written claim to the Chittagong Port Authority (for the Dhaka office) or Mongla Port Authority (if the dockworkers were based in Mongla), specifying the amount of debt incurred and the employee details. The port authority will then settle the claim on behalf of the dockworkers.

An HR manager of a large textile manufacturing company with 1,500 employees in Chittagong discovers that some employees have not received their wages for two months due to the dissolution of the local management board. The company has insufficient funds to pay all employees immediately. What should be done?

The HR manager should immediately inform the employee union and submit a written request to the Bangladesh Labour Ministry or the relevant labour inspectorate for assistance in resolving the wage dispute. The ministry may provide temporary relief, such as waiving interest on outstanding wages or providing advance payments to employees until regular wages can be paid.
What is the minimum percentage of a worker's monthly basic wages that they must subscribe to the provident fund every month?
Not less than seven percent and not more than eight per cent
What happens if an employer fails to deduct the minimum percentage of a worker's monthly basic wages for provident fund?
An employer who fails to deduct the required percentage may be subject to penalties, fines, or even prosecution under the Labour Act.
Can employers choose not to contribute to the provident fund if they are unable to pay the minimum percentage of their workers' wages?

No, employers are required by law to contribute to the provident fund at least seven percent of a worker's monthly basic wages. They cannot opt out or reduce their contribution unless they can demonstrate financial hardship.

Rahul Enterprises, a medium-sized textile manufacturing company in Dhaka with 500 employees, wants to ensure compliance with the Bangladesh Labour Law. The company's monthly basic wages for its workers range from BDT 8,000 to BDT 15,000. What percentage of their monthly basic wages must they contribute to the provident fund every month?
Not less than seven percent and not more than eight per cent 2006 (amended up to 2018). This applies to all employees, regardless of their level or department.

Amit, a newly hired employee at TechCorp, a software development company in Chittagong with 100 employees, receives BDT 20,000 as his monthly basic wages. Amit has been on the job for only two months and has not yet contributed to the provident fund. What is the minimum amount Amit must contribute to the provident fund?

2006 (amended up to 2018), workers are required to subscribe at least seven percent of their monthly basic wages to the provident fund every month. In this case, Amit's minimum contribution would be BDT 20,000 x 7% = BDT 1,400.

Who are authorized to nominate employer representatives on the Board of Trustees?

The employer is authorized to nominate their own representatives. - The employer shall at the commencement and during continuance, of the employment of a worker, make such entries therein relating to him from time to time as are required by this Chapter and the rules, and both employer and worker shall put their signatures thereon (2) The employer or an officer authorized by him shall issue an order within 7 (seven) days of receipt of the application or 2 (two) days prior to the commencement of leave applied for, whichever is earlier: Provided that if due to any urgent reasons the leave applied for is to commence on the date of application or within 3 (three) days thereof, such order shall be given on the day of receipt of the application (2) If such order of stoppage is given after the working hours has ended, the employer shall notify the concerned workers relating thereto, by a notice posted or hung the notice board in the section concerned or at a conspicuous place before the next working hour begins
What entity decides who will represent the workers in the Board of Trustees?
The collective bargaining agent or participation committee, whichever is applicable, has the authority to nominate worker representatives.
Who nominates and represents the employers' interests on the Board of Trustees?

The employer nominates and represents their own interests. How does the collective bargaining agent or participation committee ensure that the nominated representatives accurately represent the interests of their respective groups?

The collective bargaining agent or participation committee should ensure that the nominees are elected through a fair and transparent process, with adequate representation from various sections of workers. This may involve conducting elections, surveys, or other methods to determine the most suitable nominees.
What happens if there is no collective bargaining agent or participation committee in place, or if they fail to nominate representatives for the Board of Trustees?

In such cases, the Board of Trustees can be formed without workers' representatives. However, it is recommended that the employer nominates a representative who has been elected by the workers through other means, such as a union election or a workplace meeting.

In a small manufacturing company with 20 employees, where the workers are represented by an independent union (collective bargaining agent), who shall be nominated as representatives of the employer in the Board of Trustees?

According to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, since the workers are represented by an independent union, the collective bargaining agent shall nominate representatives of the workers. As a result, the employer will not nominate any representatives of their own for the Board of Trustees.

In a multinational IT company operating in Bangladesh with over 100 employees, where the workers are not represented by a trade union (but instead have formed a participation committee), who shall be nominated as representatives of the employer in the Board of Trustees?

Since the workers do not have a collective bargaining agent or a trade union to represent them, and instead have formed a participation committee, the employers will nominate their own representatives for the Board of Trustees. However, it is essential to ensure that the participation committee's concerns are adequately addressed in order to maintain a positive and representative workplace.
What is the duration for which members of the Board of Trustees shall hold office, and what happens if they fail to complete their term?
Members of the Board of Trustees shall hold office for a period of two years; they shall continue to hold office until their successors enter upon office
What is the term length for Board of Trustees members, and what consequences follow if they fail to complete their terms?
Members of the Board of Trustees shall hold office for a period of two years; they shall continue to hold office until their successors enter upon office
How long do Board of Trustees members serve, and what happens if they don't fulfill their term?
Members of the Board of Trustees shall hold office for a period of two years; they shall continue to hold office until their successors enter upon office
What are the terms and conditions for Board of Trustees members, and what happens if they fail to serve out their term?
Members of the Board of Trustees shall hold office for a period of two years; they shall continue to hold office until their successors enter upon office
What is the procedure for selecting or appointing new members to the Board of Trustees, and are there any specific qualifications required?

The procedure for selecting or appointing new members to the Board of Trustees is not explicitly stated in the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. However, it can be inferred that the selection process should follow established protocols within the organization. There are no specific qualifications mentioned in the Act for members of the Board of Trustees.

In a company with 50 employees, including 20 permanent staff and 30 contract workers, two members of the Board of Trustees are nearing the end of their two-year term. The company is in the textile industry and employs many migrant workers. What should be done to ensure that the Board has adequate representation?

The company should invite three new members from the permanent staff and three new members from the contract workers to fill the vacant positions on the Board of Trustees, ensuring a balanced representation as per the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. This will also help in addressing the concerns of migrant workers and promoting their welfare.

A factory with 100 employees, including 30 women workers, is facing a shortage of skilled workers due to training needs. The Board of Trustees recommends hiring contractors to fill the gap. However, the union representatives are opposed to this idea. What should be done?

The company should engage in dialogue with the union representatives and explore alternative options such as providing on-the-job training or hiring temporary staff. If necessary, the company can invite new members from the permanent staff or contract workers to join the Board of Trustees, ensuring their representation and participation in decision-making processes. This will help address the concerns of both the management and the employees.
What are the purposes for which at least half of the total accumulations in the provident fund must be invested, and what is the role of the employer in this process?

At least half of the total accumulations in the provident fund must be invested in government securities, including defence and postal saving certificates; the cost of maintenance of the provident fund shall be borne by the employer
What is the penalty for an employer who fails to bear the cost of maintenance of the provident fund?
The penalty for an employer who fails to bear the cost of maintenance of the provident fund is as per the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006.
Can the employee withdraw the amount invested in government securities before retirement, and if so, under what conditions?
Yes, the employee can withdraw the amount invested in government securities after retirement, subject to certain conditions as specified in the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006.

A private company with 50 employees in the textile industry has a provident fund. The company's total accumulations are BD 10 lakhs. At least half of this amount is to be invested in government securities. What is the minimum investment required by the company?
The minimum investment required by the company would be BD 5 lakhs, as it represents at least half of the total accumulations in the provident fund.

An employee in a small manufacturing company with 20 employees has completed 10 years of service. The employee is eligible to receive their provident fund. However, the company is unable to pay out the entire amount due to financial constraints. What is the employer's responsibility in this situation?

The employer must bear the cost of maintenance of the provident fund until the employee receives their full entitlement. This means that the company should continue to contribute to the provident fund until the employee receives their benefit, even if the company is unable to pay out the entire amount.
What is the deadline for an establishment to make necessary provisions for the constitution of a provident fund if at least three-fourths of the total number of workers demand its creation?
Within six months of the receipt of application; the provident fund shall start operation before the expiry of that period
What is the timeframe for an establishment to comply with the provident fund provision if a majority of its workers request its creation?
Within six months of the receipt of application; the provident fund shall start operation before the expiry of that period
If at least three-fourths of a factory's employees demand the constitution of a provident fund, by when must the establishment make necessary provisions for its creation?
Within six months of the receipt of application; the provident fund shall start operation before the expiry of that period
What is the deadline for an employer to establish a provident fund in response to a majority worker demand, and what happens subsequently?
Within six months of the receipt of application; the provident fund shall start operation before the expiry of that period
What happens if the establishment fails to make necessary provisions for a provident fund within the given deadline?
The establishment shall be liable to pay interest on the contributions at the rate of 9% per annum from the due date until the contribution is made.
Can an employer refuse to create a provident fund if less than three-fourths of the total number of workers demand its creation?
Yes, but only after giving a written explanation to the employees and obtaining their consent in writing.
A medium-sized garment factory with 150 employees requests to establish a provident fund due to dissatisfaction among workers. What should be the next step for the HR department?

The HR department should submit an application to the Labour Department within six months of receiving the request, stating the proposed provident fund scheme and the estimated amount to be contributed by the employer and employees. Once the application is approved, the provident fund shall start operation before its expiry.

A small construction company with 25 employees has not provided health insurance coverage for its workers due to budget constraints. However, one of the workers was injured on the job site recently. What should be the next step for the HR department?

The HR department should immediately notify the Labour Department about the injury and provide proof of the incident. The company should then submit an application to the Labour Department requesting approval for the provision of health insurance coverage for its workers, as required under Section 49 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 (amended up to 2018). The application should include details of the injured worker, the nature of the injury, and the proposed health insurance scheme.
What is the deadline for submitting a statement of accounts of income and expenditure to the Director General?
Within 1 (one) month of the submission of audit report.
What is the timeframe for submitting a statement of accounts of income and expenditure to the Director General?
Within 1 (one) month of the submission of audit report.
How long does an employer have to provide its financial records, including a statement of accounts of income and expenditure, to the Director General?
Within 1 (one) month of the submission of audit report.
When must an organization submit its statement of accounts of income and expenditure to the Director General, in accordance with Labour Law regulations?
Within 1 (one) month of the submission of audit report.
What happens if a factory fails to submit the statement of accounts within the given deadline?

The factory may be liable to pay a fine and/or penalties, as per the Bangladesh Labour Act.
