An IT company with 100 employees, operating in the software development sector, has a new employee joining the organization. The employee is not a citizen of Bangladesh and does not have a valid work permit. What are the HR's responsibilities under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

The HR must ensure that the new employee obtains a valid work permit within 30 days from the date of employment, 2006. Additionally, the HR should also provide the employee with a written declaration in three languages (Bangla, English, and Urdu) regarding their knowledge of the terms and conditions of employment, as per Section 25 of the Act.
What are the criteria for exempting an establishment from operating under Section 16 of the Act?
The Government may, on application by the employer, exempt an establishment if it is satisfied that the provident fund is working satisfactorily and the workers have no complaints against it.
What are the conditions under which an establishment can be exempted from operating under Section 16 of the Bangladesh Labour Act?
The Government may, on application by the employer, exempt an establishment if it is satisfied that the provident fund is working satisfactorily and the workers have no complaints against it.
Can a company be excused from adhering to Section 16 of the Labour Act based on its performance and worker grievances?
The Government may, on application by the employer, exempt an establishment if it is satisfied that the provident fund is working satisfactorily and the workers have no complaints against it.
Under what circumstances can a government grant an exemption to an employer under Section 16 of the Bangladesh Labour Act?
The Government may, on application by the employer, exempt an establishment if it is satisfied that the provident fund is working satisfactorily and the workers have no complaints against it.
What is the process for submitting an application to the Government for exemption under Section 16?
The employer must submit a written application to the Labour Department, along with all relevant documents and information, within the specified timeframe.
Can an establishment be exempted from operating under Section 16 if it has experienced financial difficulties or is undergoing restructuring?

No, exemptions are typically granted for establishments that have a proven track record of provident fund management and worker satisfaction. In cases of financial difficulties or restructuring, the Labour Department may consider alternative arrangements, such as phased implementation or special provisions.

A manufacturing company with 50 employees in Dhaka is facing financial difficulties. The company has not been paying the monthly provident fund contribution to the Provident Fund Trust for the past 6 months, but claims that it is working satisfactorily. What can the HR department do?

The HR department should request the employer to submit an application to the Government under Section 16 of the Act for exemption from operating under the section. The HR department should also prepare a detailed report highlighting the reasons for non-payment, the impact on workers, and the steps taken by the company to rectify the situation.

A Bangladeshi garment factory with 200 employees in Chittagong has been operating without any provident fund contributions for the past year. The government has recently launched an inspection campaign to ensure compliance with labour laws. What is the HR department's responsibility in this situation?

The HR department should immediately halt all production activities and notify the factory management to cease operation until compliance is achieved. The HR department should also prepare a report for the authorities detailing the non-compliance, the reasons behind it, and a plan of action to rectify the situation.
Who shall be appointed as members of the Board of Trustees for the Tea plantation Workers' Provident Fund?
The Chairman and three members representing employers, three members representing tea workers, and two members who are not connected with the tea industry.
Who should comprise the Board of Trustees for the Tea Plantation Workers' Provident Fund?
The Chairman and three members representing employers, three members representing tea workers, and two members who are not connected with the tea industry.
What is the composition of the Board of Trustees for the Tea Plantation Workers' Provident Fund?
The Chairman and three members representing employers, three members representing tea workers, and two members who are not connected with the tea industry.
Who will make up the Board of Trustees that oversees the Tea Plantation Workers' Provident Fund?
The Chairman and three members representing employers, three members representing tea workers, and two members who are not connected with the tea industry.

A small tea estate with 50 employees, owned by a single entrepreneur, is required to establish a Board of Trustees for the Tea plantation Workers' Provident Fund. The employer wants to appoint his cousin as one of the three employer representatives on the board. Is this acceptable under Bangladesh Labour Law?

No, it is not acceptable. According to 2006 (amended up to 2018), three members representing employers shall be appointed from a list of eligible persons nominated by the Central Board of Workers' Welfare and approved by the Government of Bangladesh. The employer's cousin does not meet this criterion as he is a family member and not an independent nominee.

A tea company in Dhaka with 150 employees has a dispute between two union leaders representing their respective groups of workers. As part of resolving the dispute, the management proposes to appoint one more worker representative on the Board of Trustees for the Tea plantation Workers' Provident Fund. Is this allowed under Bangladesh Labour Law?

Yes, it is allowed. According to 2006 (amended up to 2018), three members representing tea workers shall be appointed from a list of eligible persons nominated by the Central Board of Workers' Welfare and approved by the Government of Bangladesh. If one worker representative is already serving on the board, the management can propose to appoint another member, subject to the approval of the relevant authorities.
What is the term of office for the Chairman and other members of the Board of Trustees?
Three (3) years from the date of their appointment, unless their successors enter upon office.
What is the duration of the tenure for the Chairman and other members of the Board of Trustees in Bangladesh Labour Law?
Three (3) years from the date of their appointment, unless their successors enter upon office.
How long do the Chairman and members of the Board of Trustees serve in Bangladesh under the Labour Act 2006?
Three (3) years from the date of their appointment, unless their successors enter upon office.
Can you elaborate on the term period for the Chairman and other members of the Board of Trustees as per the amended Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The Chairman and other members of the Board of Trustees serve a term of three (3) years from the date of their appointment, expiring unless they are succeeded by new members.
What happens if the Chairman or members of the Board of Trustees fail to complete their term of office?
The Bangladesh Labour Act does not specify any consequences for failing to complete a term, but in practice, it is common for the government to reappoint them as soon as possible.
Can the Chairman and other members of the Board of Trustees be removed from office before the completion of their three-year term?
Yes, under the Appointments Committee may remove any member, including the Chairman, from office on the recommendation of the Prime Minister.

A manufacturing company with 500 employees, primarily engaged in producing textiles, has a Board of Trustees consisting of three members. The Chairman and other two members are appointed for a term of three (3) years. One of the board members is nearing the end of their term. What are the implications if no successors have been nominated or appointed?

Since the chairman and other members are appointed for a term of three (3) years, and one of them is nearing the end of their term without any successor being nominated or appointed, it means that the board's term has not yet expired. According to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, the Chairman and other members serve until their successors enter upon office. However, since no successors have been nominated or appointed, the current board members would need to be re-appointed for another three-year term if they wish to continue serving.

A garment factory with 150 employees, mostly female, has a Board of Trustees consisting of two members. The Chairman is a senior employee who was recently appointed for a three (3) year term. According to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, what are the implications if the Chairman's successor enters upon office within the first six months of their appointment?

If the Chairman's successor enters upon office within the first six months of their appointment, it means that they have assumed office earlier than the completion of the previous term. According to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, since the Chairman and other members serve for three (3) years, but can be removed by the Labour Department at any time without notice, if a successor assumes office within six months, it may raise concerns about potential governance or management issues. The factory should ensure that the new Chairman's appointment complies with all applicable laws and regulations to maintain legitimacy.
How much administrative charge can be levied by the Board of Trustees on the basis of subscription?
The Board of Trustees may levy an administrative charge based on subscription, as fixed by the Government in consultation with the Board.
What is the basis for determining the administrative charge levied by the Board of Trustees?
The administrative charge is typically determined as a percentage of the subscription amount, but this may vary based on the specific rules and regulations set by the Government.
How often does the Government review and update the fixed rate of administrative charges for the Board of Trustees?

The Government reviews and updates the fixed rate of administrative charges periodically, usually in consultation with the Board of Trustees to ensure that it remains reasonable and aligned with industry standards.

A medium-sized clothing factory (with 500 employees) wants to hire a new staff member. The government has fixed an administrative charge of Tk. 500 per month on subscriptions for the Board of Trustees. If the employee's monthly salary is Tk. 15000, how much will the employer pay as an administrative charge?

The employer will pay Tk. 500 (as per the subscription rate) since the employee's monthly salary is less than or equal to Tk. 10000 (maximum fixed by the Labour Ministry under Section 33A of the Bangladesh Labour Act). The employer should also ensure that the total wages paid to the new staff member do not exceed Tk. 25000 per month, as stipulated in Section 34 of the Act.

A small IT company (with 20 employees) is facing financial difficulties and wants to lay off an employee due to retrenchment. The Labour Ministry has specified that at least two days' wages should be paid to the retrenched worker as a severance package. If the retrenched employee has worked for 6 months, what amount will the employer need to pay?

The employer needs to pay Tk. 4320 (two days' wages) to the retrenched employee. According to Section 25 of the Bangladesh Labour Act, the total severance package should be calculated based on the last drawn wages and should not exceed three months' wages. The employer can deduct the amount from the next month's salary or pay it in cash. It is essential to maintain proper records and obtain necessary approvals before making any payment.
What is the payment schedule for administrative charges by employers to the Provident Fund?
Employers shall pay the administrative charge within 15 (fifteen) days of the close of every month.
Are there any penalties for not paying administrative charges on time?
Yes, the Employer shall be liable to pay a fine of TK. 10 per day for each day after the due date.
Does this payment schedule apply only to registered employers or also to those who have applied for registration?
This payment schedule applies to all employers who are required to register with the Provident Fund, including both registered and unregistered employers.

Rahul, a HR Manager of a medium-sized textile manufacturing company ( employs 200 workers) with annual average salary of Taka 120,000 each. The company is required to deduct 8% of the total monthly salaries for Provident Fund. How should Rahul calculate and pay the administrative charges to the Provident Fund?

Rahul needs to calculate 8% of the total monthly salaries (assuming 20 working days in a month) and then find 1/100th of that amount as the administrative charge. For example, if the monthly salary is Taka 2,400,000 (200 workers x 12 x 120,000), the Provident Fund contribution would be Taka 192,000 (8% of 2,400,000). The administrative charge would be Taka 192,000 / 100 = Taka 1,920. Rahul should pay this amount within 15 days of the close of every month.

A small food processing unit with 30 employees, where all workers are employed on a casual basis (no fixed-term contract) and earn an average monthly salary of Taka 80,000 each. The employer wants to terminate one employee's service without following the necessary procedure. What is the employer's liability in this case?

The employer must give the casual worker a notice period of at least two weeks (14 days). If the employer fails to do so, it will be liable for one month's wages plus arrears of wages for the next three months. In addition, the employer may also have to pay a termination charge of 1 week's wages per year of service, but this is not applicable in this case as the employee has less than two years of service. Therefore, the employer must pay one month's wages plus arrears of wages for the next three months, which would be Taka 240,000 (30 employees x 80,000 x 3).
How much percentage of basic wages shall an employer pay as subscription to the provident fund for a worker employed for more than 1 year?
Seven and a half per cent of the basic wages for the time being payable to that worker.
What is the total percentage of basic wages that an employer needs to pay as subscription to the provident fund for a worker employed for more than 1 year, including the employer's contribution?
The employer's contribution is not specified in the question, however, it is known that the total contribution (both employer and employee) is 7.5% of the basic wages.
Is there any specific time frame for deducting the provident fund contribution from an employee's basic wages?

According to the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, the employer shall deduct the provident fund contribution not less than one-third of the total amount due to the worker at the end of every month, but not exceeding the employee's basic wages.
A small-scale garment factory with 50 employees, employing workers for more than 1 year, has not been paying the required 7.5% subscription to their provident fund. What action should be taken by HR?

HR should immediately notify the employer of the non-compliance and request them to pay the arrears. If the employer refuses, HR should file a complaint with the Bangladesh Labour Department and seek their assistance in recovering the arrears.

A newly hired worker in a IT company, having basic wages of BDT 50,000 per month, has been employed for less than 1 year. According to the Labour Act, what is the subscription percentage that should be paid to their provident fund?
According to the Bangladesh Labour Act, no provident fund contribution is required from an employer for a worker employed for less than 1 year.
What happens if an employer defaults on payment of subscription to the provident fund or any charges under this Chapter? Can damages be recovered from the employer?
Yes, damages at the rate not exceeding 25% (twenty five percent) of the amount of such arrear can be recovered by the Board of Trustees.
What penalties can be imposed on an employer if it fails to pay its provident fund subscription or other charges as per the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
Damages at the rate not exceeding 25% (twenty five percent) of the amount of such arrear can be recovered by the Board of Trustees.
Can an employer who defaults on provident fund payments or other charges under the Labour Act face legal consequences and how much can they be liable for?
Yes, damages at the rate not exceeding 25% (twenty five percent) of the amount of such arrear can be recovered by the Board of Trustees.
What recourse does an employee or the Board of Trustees have if an employer fails to make provident fund payments or pay other required charges under the Labour Act?
Yes, damages at the rate not exceeding 25% (twenty five percent) of the amount of such arrear can be recovered by the Board of Trustees.
How can the Board of Trustees initiate a case against an employer who defaults on payment of subscription to the provident fund or any charges under this Chapter?
The Board of Trustees can initiate a case by filing a complaint with the Labour Appellate Tribunal.
Are there any specific time limits for the Board of Trustees to recover damages from an employer who has defaulted on payment of subscription to the provident fund or any charges under this Chapter?
According to no period of limitation shall apply against the Board of Trustees in recovering the amount due from the employer.

Rahul Enterprises, a medium-sized manufacturing company with 50 employees, has not paid the provident fund subscription for the past two years. The employee union has filed a complaint against Rahul Enterprises with the Labour Department. What are the possible outcomes and damages that can be recovered by the Board of Trustees?

The Labour Department may impose fines or penalty on Rahul Enterprises for non-payment of provident fund subscription. Additionally, the Board of Trustees can recover damages at the rate not exceeding 25% (twenty five percent) of the amount of such arrear. The employee union may also claim additional compensation under Section 67 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. It is essential for Rahul Enterprises to pay the provident fund subscription in full, including the interest and penalties, within a specified time frame as per the Labour Department's order.

A small shop owner, Md. Rashed, has employed two part-time workers under an informal agreement. He has not registered their employment with the Labour Department or paid provident fund subscription on their behalf. The workers have recently filed a complaint against Md. Rashed with the Labour Court. What are the potential consequences for Md. Rashed?

Md. Rashed may face penalties and fines under Section 63 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 for employing workers without registering their employment with the Labour Department. The Labour Court can also order Md. Rashed to pay provident fund subscription arrears, including interest and penalties, at a rate not exceeding 25% (twenty five percent) of the amount of such arrear. Furthermore, Md. Rashed may be held liable for damages under Section 67 of the Act, which could result in significant financial losses. It is essential for Md. Rashed to register his employees' employment with the Labour Department and pay their provident fund subscription promptly.
What is protected in case of a worker's death and how does it relate to provident fund payments?
The amount standing to the credit of any worker in his account at the time of his death shall vest in his nominee, subject to any deduction under other laws.
What happens to a worker's remaining balance in their provident fund account after their death?
The amount standing to the credit of any worker in his account at the time of his death shall vest in his nominee, subject to any deduction under other laws.
How does the law treat a worker's Provident Fund balance upon their passing?
The amount standing to the credit of any worker in his account at the time of his death shall vest in his nominee, subject to any deduction under other laws.
What provision is made for the distribution of a deceased worker's provident fund balance?
The amount standing to the credit of any worker in his account at the time of his death shall vest in his nominee, subject to any deduction under other laws.
What happens to the accrued provident fund when a worker dies and their nominee receives the vested amount?
The accrued provident fund of the deceased worker shall also vest in the nominee, according to 2006.
Can the employer deduct any amount from the vested amount before it is paid to the nominee as per the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
No, the employer cannot deduct any amount from the vested provident fund amount without the prior approval of the relevant authorities, 2006.

In a small-scale manufacturing company with 10 employees, one of the workers dies suddenly due to an accident on the job. The worker had been contributing to the Provident Fund for 5 years. According to the Bangladesh Labour Act, what happens to the worker's Provident Fund contribution?

The amount standing to the credit of the worker in his account at the time of death will vest in his nominee, subject to any deduction under other laws. Therefore, the entire 5-year contribution will be transferred to the nominee, assuming there are no other deductions or claims against the fund.

A large IT company in Bangladesh has an employee who retires after 20 years of service and receives a lump sum payment as severance pay. However, during the payment process, it is discovered that the employee had taken a loan from the company's Provident Fund account without permission. According to the Bangladesh Labour Act, how will this affect the payment of the severance pay?

The discovery of the unauthorized loan will result in deductions from the severance pay, as per the provisions of the Bangladesh Labour Act. The exact amount of deduction will depend on the applicable laws and regulations regarding Provident Fund misappropriation. Therefore, the company may need to adjust the payment accordingly.
Can an employer reduce wages or amenities due to liability for payment of subscription or charges under this Act?
No, an employer shall not reduce wages or other benefits by reason only of their liability for payment of any subscription or charges under this Act.
Is it permissible for an employer to lower employee wages or benefits due to their financial liability under the Labour Act?
No, an employer shall not reduce wages or other benefits by reason only of their liability for payment of any subscription or charges under this Act.
Can an employer deduct employee wages solely to cover their own liability for Labour Act-related subscriptions or fees?
No, an employer shall not reduce wages or other benefits by reason only of their liability for payment of any subscription or charges under this Act.
Are employers allowed to compromise on employees' salaries or perks due to their responsibility to pay Labour Act-related expenses?
No, an employer shall not reduce wages or other benefits by reason only of their liability for payment of any subscription or charges under this Act.
What are the implications of not paying subscription or charges under this Act on an employer?
An employer who fails to pay subscription or charges under this Act may be liable to pay penalties, fines, and other consequences as per the law.
Can an employer set aside a portion of employee wages for payment of subscription or charges under this Act without reducing other benefits?
Yes, an employer can set aside a portion of employee wages specifically for payment of subscription or charges under this Act, and the remaining amount will be paid as regular wages.
What is the penalty for an employer who fails to comply with an order of the Labour Court under section 33?
The employer shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to 3 (three) months, or with fine which may extend to 5,000 (five thousand) taka, or with both.
A medium-sized textile manufacturing company with 50 employees in Bangladesh fails to deposit the employee wages for two consecutive months. What steps should the HR department take?

The HR department should immediately notify the Employees' Provident Trust (EPT) or the Trade Unions representing the employees and initiate an investigation into the matter. Under failure to deposit wages is punishable with imprisonment for a term that may extend to three months or with a fine that may extend to five thousand taka.
A large construction company in Dhaka has employed six migrant workers from India on a contract basis without registering them under the Bangladesh Labour Act. What action should be taken by HR?

The HR department must immediately report the incident to the Department of Labour and Employment and seek registration for the migrant workers (1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act, which requires all employment agencies to register foreign workers. Failure to comply with this provision may result in penalties and fines under Section 33 of the Act.
What is the penalty for an employer who employs a child or adolescent in contravention of any provision of the Act?
The employer shall be punished with fine which may extend to 5,000 (five thousand) taka.
Can the penalty amount of 5,000 taka be waived or reduced under any circumstances?

The Bangladesh Labour Act does not specify any circumstances under which the penalty amount can be waived or reduced. However, the decision to waive or reduce the penalty lies with the relevant authorities and may depend on individual cases.
Is the 5,000 taka fine in addition to other penalties that an employer might face for violating labour laws?

Yes, the 5,000 taka fine is in addition to other penalties that an employer might face, such as closure of establishment, suspension of licence, or imprisonment. The specific penalty imposed will depend on the severity of the offence and the relevant provisions of the Act.

A small textile manufacturing company with 20 employees, located in Dhaka city, has hired a 14-year-old boy to work as an apprentice without obtaining the required 'No Objection Certificate' from the child's parent/guardian. What should be done by the HR department?

The HR department should immediately report this incident to the labour department and obtain the required 'No Objection Certificate' from the child's parent/guardian within 24 hours. The company should also issue a warning to the employee and provide compensation to the child for any harm caused or loss incurred due to non-compliance with the Act.

A medium-sized construction company, employing 50 workers, has been found to have hired 5 migrant workers from India without providing them with a written employment contract. What is the first course of action that the HR department should take?

The HR department should immediately issue a written notice to all 55 employees (including the 5 migrant workers) requiring them to sign a written employment contract within 15 days. The company should also provide these migrant workers with their passport, visa details, and other necessary documents, of the Act.
If a woman worker works for cash or kind during her permitted period of absence under Chapter IV, what is the penalty?
She shall be punished with fine which may extend to 1,000 (one thousand) taka.
Can the fine be recovered from the woman worker if she doesn't pay it?
Yes, as per the Bangladesh Labour Act, the fine can be recovered by serving a notice on the worker and deducting the amount from her wages.
Does this penalty apply to women workers only or is it applicable to all workers who work for cash or kind during permitted period of absence?
This penalty applies to all workers, regardless of their gender, if they work for cash or kind during their permitted period of absence under Chapter IV.

A mid-sized textile manufacturing company with 100 employees is considering hiring temporary workers for the upcoming Ramadan season. However, one of the female employees informs HR that she has received cash compensation from her employer during her permitted period of absence under Chapter IV of the Bangladesh Labour Act. What should be done?

The HR department should immediately inform the supervisor or manager about the incident and request an explanation for the payment. If it is confirmed that the payment was made in violation of the Labour Act, the company should provide compensation to the employee as per the Act (Section 104) and also take disciplinary action against the employer who provided the cash compensation.

A small food processing factory with 20 employees receives a complaint from one of its female workers alleging that she was asked to work for two hours without any break or remuneration during her permitted period of absence under Chapter IV. What should be the employer's response?

The employer should immediately acknowledge the complaint and assure the worker that it will investigate the matter further. If found guilty, the employer should provide compensation to the employee as per the Act (Section 104) and also take disciplinary action against the supervisor or manager who allowed the worker to work without remuneration during her permitted period of absence. Additionally, the employer should ensure that all employees are provided with adequate rest breaks and remuneration during their permitted periods of absence.
What is the procedure for an employer who has been found guilty of contravention of section 67?

What are the consequences for an employer found liable for violating Section 67 of the Bangladesh Labour Act?
The Court shall pass an order to the employer concerned to give the worker the benefit under Chapter IV, which he was deprived of. Additionally, the Court may impose a fine
If an employer is found guilty of contravention of Section 67, what should be the next course of action?
The Court shall pass an order to the employer concerned to give the worker the benefit under Chapter IV of which he was deprived. Additionally, the Court may impose a fine
What are the penalties and remedies available to a worker whose rights have been denied by an employer found guilty of violating Section 67?
The Court shall pass an order to the employer concerned to give the worker the benefit under Chapter IV, which he was deprived of. Additionally, the Court may impose a fine
What exactly does Chapter IV refer to in the context of Section 67 contravention?

Chapter IV of the Bangladesh Labour Act refers to the provisions related to social security benefits for workers, including pension and medical facilities. When an employer is found guilty of violating Section 67, the court may order them to provide the worker with the benefits they were denied.
Can the fine imposed under Section 284 be recovered directly from the employer or is it payable by the employer through the fines collection process established under the Labour Act?
The fine imposed can be recovered directly from the employer, and in some cases, it may also involve recovery of the fine through the established fines collection process under the Labour Act.

A small-scale textile factory with 50 employees in Dhaka is found guilty of violating section 67 of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. The court orders them to pay back the housing allowance given to an employee who was dismissed without proper cause. If the employer fails to comply, a fine of BDT 5,000 will be imposed. What should the HR department do next?

The HR department should ensure that the fine is paid within the specified timeframe and also verify with the court if there are any further instructions regarding the reinstatement of the dismissed employee or payment of additional compensation to the affected worker.

A large IT company in Chittagong with over 500 employees has been found guilty of violating section 67 for not providing a safe working environment. As per the court's order, the employer must provide the benefits under Chapter IV that were denied due to the violation. However, the company is hesitant to comply. What steps should be taken by the HR department to address this situation?

The HR department should communicate with the management to understand their concerns and negotiate a plan for compliance, which may include providing alternative compensation or benefits to affected employees. Additionally, the HR department should prepare a timeline for implementation and submit it to the court for approval.
Can an employer delegate its powers to a subordinate officer or person?
Yes, subject to the rules made in this behalf, the competent authority may, by order in writing, delegate all or any of its powers to any person or officer subordinate to him.
What constitutes a 'subordinate officer' under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
A subordinate officer is an employee of the employer who has been assigned specific duties and powers by the employer, as approved by the competent authority.
Are there any restrictions on the types of powers that can be delegated to a subordinate officer, and if so, what are they?

Yes, the types of powers that can be delegated must not exceed those of the original power, and cannot result in a loss of the rights or duties of an employee. The competent authority must ensure that the delegation does not compromise the employer's obligations under the Act.

In a small manufacturing company with 20 employees, including 5 supervisors, the owner-employer decides to delegate his power to assign overtime work to all employees during peak production periods. However, there is no clear policy in place regarding the delegation of such powers. What should be done?

The employer should prepare a written policy outlining the criteria for delegating power to assign overtime work and obtain approval from the competent authority (in this case, the Ministry of Labour and Employment). This will ensure that the power is exercised fairly and in accordance with the law.

A large IT company in Dhaka, employing over 1000 employees, has a well-established performance appraisal system. However, during a recent inspection by the labour department, it was discovered that one of the supervisors had been making decisions on employee promotions and discipline without consulting the competent authority. What action should be taken?

The company should immediately address this issue by recalling the supervisor's powers to make decisions on employee promotions and discipline and obtain approval from the competent authority before exercising such powers. The company should also review its internal policies and procedures to ensure that they align with the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 and prevent similar instances in the future.
What is the maximum fine that can be imposed on an employer who pays wages below the minimum rate of wages?
The maximum fine that can be imposed on an employer who pays wages below the minimum rate of wages is up to 5,000 taka.

Two employees, Md. Rashed and Md. Iqbal, work at a small manufacturing company in Dhaka with 10 employees. The company has not paid the minimum wage for the last three months. What should be the first course of action for HR?

The HR department should immediately notify the Bangladesh Labour Department about the non-payment of wages below the minimum rate. They should also inform the employees and provide them with their unpaid wages, in accordance with 2006.

A large IT company in Chittagong has hired a foreign worker on a contract basis. The worker's salary is Tk. 15,000 per month, which is below the minimum wage rate of Tk. 18,800 per month for the respective job category. What is the maximum fine that can be imposed on the employer?
The maximum fine that can be imposed on the employer is up to Tk. 5,000. This fine will be applicable under 2006 for violating the provision regarding payment of wages below the minimum rate.
How much imprisonment can an employer face for failing to give notice of accidents resulting in serious bodily injury?
An employer can face imprisonment for a term that may extend to 6 months if the accident results in serious bodily injury.

In the context of the Bangladesh Labour Act, serious bodily injury may include severe physical harm, disability, or loss of organs.
Can an employer also face imprisonment for failing to give notice of accidents resulting in less severe injuries or fatalities?
No, under the Bangladesh Labour Act, imprisonment is specifically mentioned only for accidents resulting in 'serious bodily injury', not for lesser injuries or fatalities.

However, on January 1st, an employee suffered serious bodily injury during a machine malfunction. The employer failed to give immediate notice to the authorities and didn't submit the required report within the stipulated time limit. What is the potential legal consequence for the employer?
The employer can face imprisonment for a term that may extend to 6 months due to failing to provide immediate notice of accidents resulting in serious bodily injury 2006 (amended up to 2018).

The employer failed to provide necessary medical attention immediately and didn't inform the authorities about the accident within the required timeframe. What is the potential course of action taken by the labour department against the employer?

What specific documents can a Labour Inspector seize, and are there any conditions or limitations on the seizure process?

What is the definition of a manufacturing process under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

A manufacturing process includes any activity or operation that involves the production, processing, treatment, manufacture, alteration, transportation, storage, exportation, importation, or sale of goods.
Can a person who is employed as a clerk in a non-manufacturing establishment be classified as an employee and entitled to labour rights?

Yes, under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, any person who is employed, including clerks, in a non-manufacturing establishment is considered an employee and is entitled to various labour rights, such as minimum wage, overtime pay, and social security benefits.

A small manufacturing company with 10 employees, operating a textile factory in Dhaka, is considering hiring a part-time clerk to handle administrative tasks. The clerk will only work on the office premises and not be involved in any production process. Is this person considered a worker under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

Yes, despite working exclusively in an office setting, the clerk is still considered a worker as they are engaged in non-manufacturing activities that contribute to the overall operation of the factory.

A startup IT company with 50 employees in Dhaka has hired multiple freelancers (writers, designers, developers) who work remotely and on a project-by-project basis. These individuals do not have any fixed employment contracts or regular working hours. Are these freelancers considered workers under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

No, as they are engaged in non-manufacturing activities (writing, designing, developing), they are not covered under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006 unless their services involve manufacturing processes. Their freelance nature and lack of fixed employment contracts distinguish them from traditional employees.

What are the criteria for excavation to be deemed not a mine under Section 2(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?
The excavation must not involve more than 50 persons and must not be a regularly recurring operation.
Are there any other factors that could affect whether an excavation is deemed a mine, besides the number of employees involved?
Yes, the court's discretion is also considered in determining whether an excavation should be classified as a mine.

What is the definition of a mine under Section 2(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006, and how does it differ from an excavation?

A mine is defined as any work or operation consisting of digging or extracting coal, iron ore, gypsum, limestone, marble, granite, sand, gravel, or other mineral-bearing rock, involving removal of earth or rock material by hand tools, drilling machines, blasting, or mechanical excavators. In contrast to an excavation, a mine involves extraction and processing of minerals, whereas an excavation typically refers to the digging of foundations, tunnels, or shafts for construction purposes.
Are there any specific safety measures or permits required for excavations below 6 metres in depth, and what are the penalties for non-compliance?

Yes, excavations below 6 metres require a permit from the Directorate of Labour Welfare. Failure to obtain a permit or comply with safety standards can result in fines ranging from BDT 50,000 to BDT 500,000 and imprisonment up to 7 years under 2006.

A manufacturing company with 500 employees in the garment industry has a large excavation site to extract coal for its production process. The excavation is approximately 7 meters deep, exceeding the minimum depth requirement of 6 meters under Section 2(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. What measures should the HR department take to ensure compliance with the law?

The HR department should immediately notify the Director General of Factories and Works and the Department of Labour in writing, outlining the location, depth, and purpose of the excavation. The company must also ensure that all workers involved in the excavation are aware of the hazards and have received proper training on safety procedures. Additionally, the company should conduct regular inspections to identify potential risks and implement necessary safety measures.

A small retail shop with 20 employees in the commercial sector has a makeshift storage room that is 4 meters deep, which could be considered an excavation under Section 2(1) of the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006. What actions should the HR department take to comply with the law?

The HR department should conduct a site inspection to verify the depth and purpose of the storage room. If it is deemed an excavation, the company must notify the Director General of Factories and Works within 7 working days. The company should also ensure that all workers involved in accessing or using the storage room have received proper training on safety procedures and follow all necessary safety measures to prevent accidents.

Is the Tk/-200,000 compensation amount paid in one lump sum or in installments over time?

Scenario question 1: A worker, Rahim, has been working as a textile factory inspector for the last 10 years. He suffers from silicosis due to prolonged exposure to silica dust during his work. After several medical tests, it is confirmed that he is suffering from occupational disease. What compensation should be paid to Rahim under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

2006 (amended up to 2018), if a worker dies due to an occupational disease, the employer shall pay an amount not exceeding Tk/-200,000 as compensation. Since Rahim is alive and suffering from the occupational disease, he is entitled to receive compensation of the Act. The employer should pay an amount not exceeding Tk/-20,000 (1/10th of the maximum compensation for death) per month as medical treatment expenses until Rahim receives full compensation or permanently incapacitated. Additionally, Rahim may file a claim for full compensation of the Act if his condition worsens or he dies due to the occupational disease.

Scenario question 2: A worker, Jahanara, has been working as a shop assistant at a small retail store in Dhaka for 5 years. She suffers from asthma-like symptoms and is diagnosed with occupational asthma due to frequent exposure to dust and allergens during her work. What compensation should be paid to Jahanara under the Bangladesh Labour Act 2006?

2006 (amended up to 2018), a worker suffering from an occupational disease shall receive medical treatment expenses until full compensation is received or permanently incapacitated. However, since Jahanara's condition is not life-threatening and she can still perform her job duties with some restrictions, she may not be entitled to the maximum compensation amount of Tk/-20,000 per month as specified in Section 113. The employer should pay a reasonable monthly allowance to help Jahanara manage her symptoms while working, such as Tk/-5,000-10,000 per month, depending on the severity of her condition and her ability to perform her job duties.

What is considered a 'prolonged occupational disease' under the Bangladesh Labour Act?
A prolonged occupational disease is one that persists for at least two years and has been caused or aggravated by exposure to hazardous factors in the workplace.
Are there any exceptions to the 2-year limit for disablement due to prolonged occupational disease, such as if the employee dies or becomes permanently disabled?
Yes, if an employee's disability is permanent or they die due to the occupational disease, the period of disablement can exceed 2 years and the employer must pay compensation accordingly.

A manufacturing company in Dhaka with 50 employees is facing a shortage of skilled workers. The company wants to hire foreign workers from neighboring countries. Under the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, what specific requirements and restrictions apply to hiring foreign workers?

To hire foreign workers, the company must obtain a work permit from the relevant authorities. Foreign workers are required to register with the Bureau of Manpower Administration within two weeks of arrival. The company is also required to provide proof of having obtained necessary qualifications and experience for the job, and ensure that the wages and working conditions meet the standards set by the Bangladesh Labour Act. Additionally, foreign workers must be repatriated or allowed to seek work in their home country after completing a minimum 2-year service term.

An employee of a garment factory in Chittagong has been on leave for over six months due to maternity leave and is expecting her second child. Under the Bangladesh Labour Act, 2006, what benefits and support does she entitle herself to?

The employee is entitled to receive full salary during her leave period of up to six months under the Maternity Leave Ordinance. She will also be entitled to a cash allowance of Tk. 1 lakh for the first child and Tk. 2 lakh for the second child, as per the provisions of the Bangladesh Labour Act. Furthermore, she is eligible for medical benefits during her maternity leave period, including pre-conception and post-natal care, as well as childcare support after returning to work.
